It’s a dream base if you love chic seaside atmospheres, boat trips and long aperitivos as the sun sinks behind the headlands.
porto cervo italy.highlights: Crystal-clear sea and sheltered coves ideal for swimming and snorkeling. | Elegant marina lined with yachts, cafés and stylish waterfront restaurants. | High-end boutiques and luxury hotels for a premium seaside stay. | Boat excursions along the Costa Smeralda and to nearby islands. | Scenic coastal roads and viewpoints for sunset drives and photo stops.
porto cervo italy.bonus: Reserve a sunset boat trip to a secluded cove, where you can dive into turquoise water and toast the evening with a glass of chilled Vermentino.

franschhoek south africa.desc: Franschhoek, in South Africa’s Cape Winelands, is a small valley town framed by vineyards and dramatic mountains. Here you can hop between historic wine estates, linger over long lunches at acclaimed restaurants and wander through a village centre filled with galleries and boutiques. A wine tram or bike ride lets you taste your way through the countryside without rushing. It’s an inspired choice if you love food, wine and slow days surrounded by scenery that looks like a painting.
franschhoek south africa.highlights: Renowned wine estates offering tastings with views over the Franschhoek Valley. | Excellent restaurants that have earned the town its “food capital” reputation. | Scenic hikes and bike routes in the surrounding mountains and nature reserves. | Charming main street with art galleries, cafés and small independent shops. | Easy day-trip distance from Cape Town yet with a tranquil, rural feel.
franschhoek south africa.bonus: Ride the Franschhoek Wine Tram for a relaxed day of tastings, vineyard views and photo stops without having to drive between wineries.

jackson hole usa.desc: Jackson Hole in Wyoming is a wide valley framed by the jagged Teton Range and huge skies. In winter you can carve steep slopes at Jackson Hole Mountain Resort, explore quieter runs at nearby hills and unwind in a hot tub as the snow falls. Summer brings hiking, rafting and wildlife‑spotting in Grand Teton and Yellowstone, both just a short drive away. It’s a strong pick if you love big‑mountain scenery, outdoor adventure and a dose of authentic Western atmosphere.
jackson hole usa.highlights: World-class skiing and snowboarding with long, challenging runs and deep powder. | Easy access to Grand Teton and Yellowstone national parks for day trips. | Summer activities from hiking and biking to rafting on the Snake River. | Lively mix of rustic lodges, cosy cabins and upscale mountain resorts. | Western‑style town of Jackson with galleries, saloons and live music.
jackson hole usa.bonus: Take an early‑morning wildlife tour into Grand Teton, when moose, elk and bison are most active and the first light hits the Teton peaks.

auckland new zealand.desc: Auckland in New Zealand is a harbour city where sailboats, skyline and green volcanic hills all share the same horizon. Along the waterfront you can stroll between cafés, piers and public art before hiking up Mount Eden or One Tree Hill for crater views over both harbours. Fast ferries link downtown to islands such as Waiheke, with vineyards, beaches and easy coastal walks. If you like combining urban energy, sea air and simple day trips into nature, Auckland makes a very flexible base.
auckland new zealand.highlights: Lively waterfront promenades with cafés, bars and harbour viewpoints. | Short walks up extinct volcanoes for wide city-and-sea panoramas. | Frequent ferries to Waiheke and nearby islands with beaches and wineries. | Year-round outdoor lifestyle with parks, coastal paths and sailing.
auckland new zealand.bonus: Climb Mount Eden in the late afternoon and stay as the sun sets over both sparkling harbours.

mont tremblant canada.desc: In Québec’s Laurentian Mountains, Mont-Tremblant is a compact resort where a colourful pedestrian village sits at the foot of forested slopes. In winter you ski, snowboard or snowshoe almost straight from your hotel door, then warm up in cafés and après-ski bars back in the village. When the snow melts, hiking trails, mountain bike routes, golf courses and cruises on Lac Tremblant take over. A panoramic gondola whisks you to the summit for big views and sunset skies, making Mont-Tremblant an easy all-season base for outdoor lovers.
mont tremblant canada.highlights: Pedestrian alpine village with cafés, boutiques and après-ski spots. | Varied ski terrain plus snowshoeing, cross-country and other winter activities. | Summer hiking, biking, golf and lake excursions on Lac Tremblant. | Panoramic gondola rides to the summit with sweeping Laurentian views.
mont tremblant canada.bonus: Book a late-afternoon gondola ride and watch the mountains turn pink before descending to the village lights.

opatija croatia.desc: Opatija on Croatia’s Kvarner Bay is a graceful seaside town of grand villas, palm-lined promenades and views towards the islands of Krk and Cres. Belle Époque hotels, manicured parks and shaded café terraces still hint at the days when Habsburg aristocrats came here for the mild sea air. You can stroll for kilometres along the Lungomare coastal path, stopping at small beaches and bathing terraces, or head up towards Mount Učka for cooler forest walks. Opatija suits travellers who enjoy a calm, slightly nostalgic atmosphere by the sea rather than loud nightlife.
opatija croatia.highlights: Elegant seafront Lungomare with long, flat walks right by the water. | Historic villas, grand hotels and gardens from the Austro-Hungarian era. | Rocky coves and bathing platforms with clear Adriatic water. | Easy access to Kvarner islands and nearby hill villages for day trips.
opatija croatia.bonus: Follow the Lungomare at dusk to the Girl with the Seagull statue and watch the lights of the bay and islands appear.

doha qatar.desc: Doha, the capital of Qatar, stretches along a wide bay where glass towers rise behind a palm-lined promenade. By day you can wander the Corniche, visit the Museum of Islamic Art or the National Museum of Qatar, and cool off in shaded parks facing the sea. In the late afternoon the Souq Waqif fills with the smell of spices, coffee and grilled meat while traditional wooden dhows glide past offshore. Doha works well if you like mixing modern architecture, museums and glimpses of desert culture in a compact city break.
doha qatar.highlights: Scenic Corniche waterfront with views of the skyline and wooden dhows. | World-class museums such as the Museum of Islamic Art and National Museum. | Atmospheric Souq Waqif with cafés, local food and evening buzz. | Easy access to desert tours, inland sea trips and dune-bashing excursions.
doha qatar.bonus: Book a dusk dhow cruise from the Corniche to watch the city light up as the call to prayer echoes across the bay.

st barts saint barth lemy.desc: St. Barts, or Saint-Barthélemy, is a small French Caribbean island where emerald hills dip into bays of bright turquoise water. Around Gustavia and St-Jean you’ll find designer boutiques, chic beach clubs and restaurants, yet the island still feels relaxed when you step onto a quiet stretch of sand. Beaches like Gouverneur, Saline or Flamands offer clear water, soft sand and good snorkeling, while winding roads pass villas hidden in the greenery. St. Barts is made for travellers who enjoy barefoot luxury, long lunches and slow days split between sea, hammock and hillside pool.
st barts saint barth lemy.highlights: Compact island with easy drives between coves, viewpoints and villages. | White-sand beaches such as St-Jean, Saline, Gouverneur and Flamands. | Chic harbour town Gustavia with boutiques, galleries and French-Caribbean dining. | Excellent conditions for sailing, snorkeling and other water sports.
st barts saint barth lemy.bonus: Hike down to the natural pools near Grand Fond or Colombier Beach for a quieter swim far from the beach clubs.

monaco monaco.desc: Monaco is a compact Mediterranean city‑state where steep cliffs drop straight into a glittering marina filled with yachts. Between the old town on the Rock and the legendary Monte Carlo district, you wander between royal palaces, designer boutiques and sea‑front promenades. Mild weather, sea views from almost every corner and easy access to nearby beaches make it ideal if you like combining urban energy with coastal relaxation. Monaco suits you if you enjoy upscale experiences, from fine dining to sunset drinks overlooking the harbor.
monaco monaco.highlights: Panoramic sea views from clifftop terraces, gardens and rooftop bars. | Easy to explore on foot thanks to its compact, walkable size. | World‑class casinos, restaurants and luxury shopping in Monte Carlo. | Mild Mediterranean climate, ideal for off‑season escapes on the Côte d’Azur.
monaco monaco.bonus: For a special moment, ride the elevators up to the Prince’s Palace at dusk and watch the lights slowly switch on around Port Hercule.

gstaad switzerland.desc: In the Swiss Alps, the village of Gstaad combines wooden chalets, green pastures and high peaks in a postcard backdrop. In winter you ski or snowboard on varied slopes spread over several connected areas, while in summer the same mountains turn into a playground for hiking and biking. The traffic‑free center with its boutiques and cafés feels relaxed rather than flashy, even though the resort is known for its upscale hotels. Gstaad works well if you want fresh mountain air with comfort and plenty of outdoor activities.
gstaad switzerland.highlights: Car‑free village center with cafés, boutiques and traditional Swiss chalets. | Access to multiple ski areas plus Glacier 3000 for high‑altitude snow. | Extensive summer hiking and biking trails through meadows and forests. | Family‑friendly atmosphere with easy runs and mountain activities for kids.
gstaad switzerland.bonus: Take the cable car up to Glacier 3000 for a walk across the peak‑to‑peak suspension bridge with vast views over the Bernese Alps.

marrakech palmeraie marocco.desc: In Marrakesh’s Palm Grove, the Palmeraie stretches like a green oasis just outside the city, with thousands of date palms against the ochre desert light. You stay in riads or resorts hidden in lush gardens, then head out for camel rides, quad‑bike adventures or a round of golf among the palms. Evenings are calm and starry here, yet the souks and Jemaa el‑Fna square are only a short drive away. This area is ideal if you want Marrakesh’s colors and flavors with more space, sun and privacy.
marrakech palmeraie marocco.highlights: Oasis setting with palm trees, gardens and desert sunsets close to the medina. | Camel rides, quad‑bike tours and guided excursions starting directly from your lodge. | Stylish riads and resorts with pools, hammams and quiet courtyards. | Easy transfers by taxi or car to Marrakesh’s souks, monuments and night markets.
marrakech palmeraie marocco.bonus: Book a late‑afternoon camel ride through the Palmeraie and finish with mint tea as the sky turns pink behind the Atlas Mountains.

courchevel francia.desc: Perched on the slopes of the French Alps, Courchevel is a chic ski resort spread over several villages within the Trois Vallées ski area. In winter you wake up almost on the pistes, with groomed runs for every level, snowparks and long journeys linking neighboring valleys. Many hotels offer ski‑in/ski‑out access, spas and refined dining, while the village centers mix designer boutiques with cosy mountain bars. Courchevel is a strong choice if you want reliable snow, big‑mountain skiing and a luxurious base for friends, couples or families.
courchevel francia.highlights: Direct access to the vast Trois Vallées ski area from multiple Courchevel villages. | Wide choice of pistes, from gentle beginner slopes to famous steep couloirs. | High‑end hotels, chalets and spas with ski‑in/ski‑out convenience. | Lively après‑ski, gourmet restaurants and family‑friendly fun zones on the mountain.
courchevel francia.bonus: On a clear day, ski from the highest lifts down to the lower villages and watch the landscape change with every turn.

meg ve france.desc: Tucked into Haute‑Savoie, Megève is a traditional Alpine village where cobbled streets, a historic church and horse‑drawn carriages give winter days a storybook feel. The ski area offers wooded runs with views towards Mont Blanc, as well as gentle slopes that work well for families and beginners. After skiing you can relax in cosy hotels with spas or explore the vibrant restaurant scene, from mountain bistros to Michelin‑starred dining. Megève suits you if you like a refined, atmospheric base rather than a purpose‑built resort.
meg ve france.highlights: Authentic village center with car‑free streets, boutiques and a centuries‑old church. | Tree‑lined pistes and scenic views towards the Mont Blanc massif. | Plenty of gentle runs and ski schools tailored to families and learners. | Excellent food scene, from cosy Savoyard restaurants to Michelin‑starred tables.
meg ve france.bonus: Take an evening horse‑drawn sleigh ride through the village lights and finish with a hot chocolate or vin chaud on the main square.

mustique st vincent and the grenadines.desc: Mustique sits in the heart of St Vincent and the Grenadines, a private island where turquoise bays and low‑key villas feel blissfully far from the world. Along its contrasting Atlantic and Caribbean shores you move from wilder surf at Macaroni Beach to calm, glassy coves perfect for lazy morning swims and snorkeling with turtles in Britannia Bay. Days drift between sailing, paddleboarding, yoga and long lunches at spots like Basil’s Bar. Mustique is ideal if you crave barefoot luxury, privacy and the feeling of having your own tropical hideaway instead of a busy resort.
mustique st vincent and the grenadines.highlights: Exclusive private island with very limited guests and no cruise-ship crowds. | Nine different beaches, from dramatic Atlantic waves to sheltered Caribbean swimming coves. | Collection of villas and one boutique hotel offering discreet, personalised service. | Excellent snorkeling, diving and sailing with coral reefs and turtles close to shore.
mustique st vincent and the grenadines.bonus: Book a late-afternoon beach picnic on Macaroni or Pasture Bay and watch the sun sink into the sea with lanterns glowing in the sand.

deer valley usa.desc: Deer Valley in Utah is a skier-only mountain above Park City, known for its immaculate groomed runs, fast lifts and polished service. You ski straight from elegant lodges onto long, perfectly prepared pistes, while ski valets handle your gear and daily ticket caps keep the slopes pleasantly uncrowded. Off the mountain you warm up in fireside lounges, enjoy refined dining and watch the lights of Park City twinkle below. It’s a great choice if you love skiing in comfort, appreciate attentive service and want an easy, upscale base for winter days in the Wasatch Range.
deer valley usa.highlights: Ski-only resort with long groomers and a wide range of difficulty levels. | Famous grooming, fast lifts and capped ticket sales that reduce crowding. | Upscale lodges, spas and fireside lounges ideal for relaxing after skiing. | Excellent ski school and family facilities for beginners and children.
deer valley usa.bonus: Book a first-tracks morning with a guide and carve fresh corduroy at sunrise before retreating for a hearty mountain breakfast.

portofino italy.desc: Portofino on the Italian Riviera is a tiny harbor village where pastel houses tumble down to a crescent of sea and bobbing yachts. You wander narrow lanes from the piazzetta up to Castello Brown and the Church of San Giorgio, pausing for espresso, gelato and views over the bay. Boat trips lead you along the protected coastline to San Fruttuoso or hidden coves, while nearby trails wind through Mediterranean vegetation to lighthouses and viewpoints. Portofino is ideal if you enjoy chic seaside atmospheres, scenic walks and long, romantic evenings on a terrace overlooking the water.
portofino italy.highlights: Iconic harbor framed by colorful façades, fishing boats and luxury yachts. | Short hikes up to Castello Brown and San Giorgio for sweeping sea views. | Easy boat access to coves and the abbey of San Fruttuoso nearby. | Refined restaurants and wine bars perfect for slow, romantic dinners.
portofino italy.bonus: Take a late-afternoon walk to the lighthouse, then sip an aperitivo as the bay glows gold and the harbor lights begin to sparkle.

anguilla anguilla.desc: Anguilla is a low‑key Caribbean island with 33 white‑sand beaches, turquoise water and a famously relaxed, friendly atmosphere. You can spend your days beach‑hopping between calm bays like Shoal Bay and Meads Bay, diving into warm, clear water that stays inviting well beyond winter. Simple beach shacks serve grilled lobster and rum punch next to more refined restaurants that have made Anguilla a small culinary capital of the region. With no high‑rises or cruise‑ship chaos, it’s perfect if you want safe, uncrowded shores, good music at sunset and a slow, barefoot rhythm.
anguilla anguilla.highlights: Powder-soft white beaches and luminous turquoise sea along almost every stretch of coast. | Easy beach-hopping between calm bays ideal for swimming and paddleboarding. | Strong culinary scene, from casual beach bars to high-end Caribbean dining. | Generally peaceful, safe island vibe suitable for couples and relaxed families.
anguilla anguilla.bonus: Join a small boat trip to little offshore cays for snorkeling above bright coral gardens followed by a barbecue lunch on an almost empty beach.

salento italy.desc: The Salento peninsula in Puglia stretches between the Adriatic and Ionian seas, mixing sunburnt olive groves with fishing towns and Baroque cities like Lecce. On the Adriatic side you find cliffs, sea caves and wild coves, while the Ionian coast offers long, sandy beaches with shallow, calm water that’s perfect for families. Inland roads wind through stone-walled countryside dotted with masserie, small villages and wineries where you can taste local olive oil and primitivo. Salento suits you if you love road trips, crystal-clear sea by day and lively piazzas filled with music and gelato at night.
salento italy.highlights: Two very different coastlines: cliffs and grottos on one side, long sandy beaches on the other. | Clear, usually calm waters ideal for swimming, snorkeling and family-friendly beach days. | Historic towns like Lecce, Otranto and Gallipoli rich in architecture and atmosphere. | Country lanes lined with olive trees, perfect for cycling and slow drives.
salento italy.bonus: Plan a day that starts with a swim in a rocky Adriatic cove, crosses inland through olive fields and ends with sunset over the Ionian Sea.

corsica france.desc: Set between France and Italy in the heart of the Mediterranean, Corsica combines wild mountains, fragrant maquis and turquoise coves on one compact island. You drive along winding coastal roads, then slip inland to chestnut forests, perched stone villages and cool river gorges where locals swim in summer. Wide sandy bays sit next to hidden coves reached by short hikes, so you can alternate relaxed beach days with panoramic walks on old mule tracks. Corsica is ideal if you love mixing road trips, outdoor adventure and slow evenings over robust local wine and charcuterie.
corsica france.highlights: Dramatic mix of sandy beaches, cliffs and crystal-clear coves around the island. | Scenic mountain roads linking coastal towns with remote hilltop villages. | Excellent hiking options, from gentle coastal paths to multi-day ridge routes. | Strong food culture with cheeses, charcuterie and wines rooted in Corsican traditions.
corsica france.bonus: Follow a stretch of the Mare e Monti trail to watch the sun set over the sea from a quiet clifftop viewpoint far from the crowds.

cornwall uk.desc: At England’s far south‑west tip, Cornwall feels like a different country, with wind‑carved cliffs, sweeping beaches and pastel harbours facing the Atlantic. You can walk stretches of the South West Coast Path between fishing villages, stopping for cream teas and cosy pubs with sea views after a day in the salt air. Surfers chase waves on wide sandy bays while families explore rock pools, smugglers’ coves and historic tin‑mining ruins above the sea. Cornwall suits you if you dream of wild coastal scenery, relaxed seaside towns and plenty of easy walks between viewpoints.
cornwall uk.highlights: Long sandy beaches and sheltered coves ideal for surfing, paddling and family days. | Iconic South West Coast Path sections with dramatic headlands and sea cliffs. | Atmospheric fishing villages with stone cottages, harbours and traditional pubs. | Plenty of activities in all seasons, from storm watching to sunny beach picnics.
cornwall uk.bonus: Follow a clifftop section of the South West Coast Path near St Ives or Land’s End for golden‑hour views over endless Atlantic swells and hidden coves.

bay of kotor montenegro.desc: Wrapped in steep mountains that drop straight into the Adriatic, the Bay of Kotor feels like a fjord but with a distinctly Mediterranean soul. Medieval Kotor hides behind stone walls, with alleyways, churches and cats sunning themselves on warm steps, while elegant Perast lines the water with baroque facades and tiny islands offshore. You can climb to a fortress for big‑screen views, take a boat across mirror‑calm water or simply wander promenades at sunset as cruise lights shimmer on the bay. The Bay of Kotor is perfect if you love atmospheric old towns, dramatic scenery and exploring by foot and boat in the same day.
bay of kotor montenegro.highlights: UNESCO‑listed bay framed by high limestone peaks and deep, sheltered waters. | Walled old town of Kotor with churches, squares and lively cafés. | Boat trips to Perast, Our Lady of the Rocks and hidden coastal spots. | Fortress hikes and new cable car rides with panoramic views over the bay.
bay of kotor montenegro.bonus: Climb the old city walls early in the morning for a peaceful panorama of mist rising off the bay before the day’s boats arrive.

paros greece.desc: In the heart of the Cyclades, Paros blends whitewashed villages, sandy beaches and relaxed island life under endlessly blue skies. You can wander through the lanes of Parikia or Naoussa, where fishing boats bob in tiny harbours and cafés spill out onto the waterfront, then head to golden beaches that slip gently into clear water. Inland, hilltop Lefkes offers marble streets, quiet chapels and views over terraced hillsides down to the sea. Paros is perfect if you want a Greek island with a bit of everything: easy village strolls, swimming spots for all ages and evenings that stretch out around good food and music.
paros greece.highlights: Soft sandy beaches from family coves to livelier shores with beach clubs. | Characterful villages like Parikia, Naoussa and Lefkes with classic Cycladic charm. | Good mix of tavernas, bars and small boutiques without losing a local feel. | Calm, clear water ideal for swimming, paddleboarding and relaxed boat trips.
paros greece.bonus: Take a late‑afternoon boat or bus to Kolymbithres or Golden Beach, then stay to watch the rocks and sea slowly turn pink in the sunset light.

menorca spain.desc: Quieter than its Balearic neighbours, Menorca is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve where turquoise coves, rolling farmland and low stone walls create a soft Mediterranean landscape. You can follow sections of the historic Camí de Cavalls coastal trail from cala to cala, stopping to swim in calm, glass‑clear water framed by pines and limestone cliffs. Inland, white villages and the old streets of Ciutadella invite slow evening strolls and tapas on shaded squares. Menorca is ideal if you’re dreaming of wild but gentle nature, secret beaches reached on foot and an island pace that naturally slows you down.
menorca spain.highlights: Over 100 coves and beaches, many still undeveloped and softly curved. | Camí de Cavalls trail encircling the island for coastal walks and bike rides. | Calm, shallow waters perfect for families, snorkeling and relaxed kayaking. | Historic towns like Ciutadella and Maó with harbourside bars and sunset viewpoints.
menorca spain.bonus: Spend an evening at a clifftop bar such as the famous cave venue near Cala en Porter, watching the sun sink straight into the Mediterranean below you.

stockholm archipelago sweden.desc: Just beyond Stockholm, the Stockholm Archipelago unfolds as a maze of 30,000 islands, pine-clad skerries and sheltered bays. You hop from wooden jetty to wooden jetty by ferry, trading the city streets for red cottages, smooth rocks warmed by the sun and clear Baltic water. Spend your days kayaking between islets, following stretches of the long-distance Stockholm Archipelago Trail or joining boat tours that stop at small harbours serving smoked fish and cinnamon buns. It’s the perfect escape if you love slow island life, Nordic light and nature that always feels close by.
stockholm archipelago sweden.highlights: Easy island-hopping from Stockholm by regular ferries and boats. | Smooth pinkish rocks for sunbathing right beside clear Baltic water. | Sea kayaking, hiking sections of the Stockholm Archipelago Trail. | Cosy cottages, saunas and small harbours with relaxed Nordic dining.
stockholm archipelago sweden.bonus: On summer evenings, take a late boat to an outer island and watch the sky turn pastel over almost-silent water before your sauna session.

kor ula croatia.desc: Korčula is a green Adriatic island off the Dalmatian coast, where a walled medieval town looks out over clear turquoise water and nearby vineyards. Inside Korčula Town’s fishbone-pattern lanes you wander past stone houses, little wine bars and Gothic-Renaissance churches before reaching the sea for an evening swim. Beyond the walls, quiet coves, sandy corners near Lumbarda and offshore islets invite you to spend long days between the beach and local konoba taverns. It’s a wonderfully relaxed choice if you want Croatia’s beauty and culture with fewer crowds and a strong taste of island life.
kor ula croatia.highlights: Compact medieval old town with sea views in almost every direction. | Mix of pebble coves and sandy beaches around the island and islets. | Local white wines like Grk and Pošip served in family-run wineries. | Easy day trips by boat to quiet bays, vineyards and nearby islands.
kor ula croatia.bonus: In summer, time your visit to a traditional Moreška sword dance performance and watch the town fill with music, costumes and sea-scented evening air.

c te de granit rose france.desc: Along Brittany’s Côte de Granit Rose in northwest France, huge rose-coloured boulders and tiny islands create a shoreline that looks almost sculpted by hand. You follow the sentier des douaniers coastal path between Perros-Guirec, Ploumanac’h and Trégastel, watching waves break around rock formations that resemble animals, castles or faces. Sheltered sandy beaches and clear shallows invite you for a swim, while nearby villages tempt you with crêpes, seafood and lighthouses perched above the sea. It’s a magical yet relaxed stretch of coast if you love seaside walks, striking landscapes and long Atlantic sunsets.
c te de granit rose france.highlights: Spectacular pink granite cliffs and boulders glowing at sunrise and sunset. | Easy coastal paths such as the sentier des douaniers between resorts. | Family-friendly sandy beaches with shallow water and nearby rock pools. | Charming Breton villages with crêperies, seafood restaurants and small harbours.
c te de granit rose france.bonus: Find a viewpoint near Ploumanac’h lighthouse at golden hour and watch the rocks slowly turn copper-pink while the tide slides quietly around them.

albanian riviera albania.desc: Stretching along Albania’s Ionian coast, the Albanian Riviera mixes wild mountains that drop into turquoise coves, small seaside towns and a road that twists between them with panoramic views. From Dhërmi to Himarë and Ksamil you find beaches that range from lively beach-club strips to pebbly bays reached by short hikes, always with extraordinarily clear water. Inland day trips lead you to UNESCO-listed sites like Butrint or stone towns such as Gjirokastër, adding history to days of swimming and long lunches. It’s an exciting choice if you want Mediterranean sun, a sense of discovery and prices that are still surprisingly gentle.
albanian riviera albania.highlights: Dramatic coastal drive with viewpoints over cliffs, coves and the Ionian Sea. | Variety of beaches, from quiet pebbly bays to buzzing summer beach clubs. | Easy access to UNESCO sites like Butrint and historic towns in the interior. | Generally lower prices than many other Mediterranean rivieras for food and stays.
albanian riviera albania.bonus: Take a boat or short hike to Gjipe or Filikuri Beach and spend the day between sheer cliffs, deep blue water and a simple taverna on the sand.

nara japan.desc: Nara, the first permanent capital of Japan, blends grand temples, tame deer and quiet streets only a short train ride from Kyoto or Osaka. In Nara Park you walk between Todaiji’s Great Buddha Hall, mossy stone lanterns of Kasuga Taisha and open lawns where deer bow in exchange for rice crackers. Just beyond, the old merchant district of Naramachi offers wooden townhouses, tiny cafés and traditional shops that slow your pace even more. Whether you come for a day trip or stay overnight, Nara suits travellers who love history, soft nature and a gentler rhythm than the big cities.
nara japan.highlights: Easy access from Kyoto and Osaka, ideal for a relaxed day trip or overnight. | Iconic sights like Todaiji Temple, Kasuga Taisha and Kofukuji around Nara Park. | Friendly deer roaming freely in the park’s lawns and forested paths. | Atmospheric Naramachi district with wooden houses, small cafés and craft boutiques.
nara japan.bonus: Visit at opening time, buy a few deer crackers and walk towards Todaiji through the morning mist, when paths, pagodas and deer are still surprisingly quiet.

c rdoba spain.desc: Cordoba, in southern Spain, wraps you in warm light, whitewashed alleys and centuries of Moorish and Christian history. You stroll from the forest of arches inside the Mezquita-Cathedral to flower-filled patios and the old Roman bridge over the Guadalquivir. Tiny tapas bars spill onto quiet squares where you can taste salmorejo, sip local wine and maybe catch an intimate flamenco show. Choose Cordoba if you love walkable cities where every corner hides a story and spring days feel long and pleasantly mild.
c rdoba spain.highlights: UNESCO-listed historic centre packed with patios, lanes and hidden little squares. | Mezquita-Cathedral’s mesmerizing forest of arches and calm interior courtyards. | Roman bridge views over the Guadalquivir, especially around sunset and blue hour. | Plenty of traditional taverns serving salmorejo, tapas and Montilla-Moriles wines. | Soft Andalusian climate that invites slow strolls for most of the year.
c rdoba spain.bonus: Seek out the Patio de los Naranjos at opening time to smell orange blossom before the crowds arrive.

lisse keukenhof netherlands.desc: Lisse and the Keukenhof Gardens in South Holland are all about spring colour and fresh air. For a few weeks each year you wander among millions of tulips, hyacinths and daffodils arranged in creative beds around ponds, pavilions and a classic windmill. Just outside the park, quiet cycle paths lead through the bulb fields towards small villages and sand dunes near the North Sea. It’s a dream if you love seasonal trips where nature, photography and gentle biking replace big-city rush.
lisse keukenhof netherlands.highlights: World-famous flower park with imaginative displays of tulips and other spring bulbs. | Easy day trip from Amsterdam, Leiden or Haarlem by bus or organised tour. | Scenic cycling routes through the surrounding bulb fields when they are in bloom. | Family-friendly paths, playgrounds and relaxed boat rides among the flowers. | Short but intense opening season, perfect excuse for a dedicated spring getaway.
lisse keukenhof netherlands.bonus: Book an early-morning or late-afternoon time slot at Keukenhof to enjoy softer light and noticeably fewer crowds in the most popular areas.

washington d c usa.desc: Washington, DC is more than politics: it’s a green, walkable capital where monuments, museums and neighbourhood cafés share the same skyline. You might spend the morning on the National Mall, moving between the Capitol, the Washington Monument and the Smithsonian museums that are free to enter. Later you drift into Georgetown or the Wharf for cobbled streets, river views and relaxed terraces along the Potomac. Washington works well if you like combining big-ticket sights with everyday city life and don’t mind four distinct seasons from cherry blossom to crisp autumn days.
washington d c usa.highlights: Iconic National Mall lined with monuments, memorials and world-class museums. | Many Smithsonian museums offer free admission, ideal for culture lovers on a budget. | Characterful neighbourhoods such as Georgetown, Dupont Circle and the Wharf waterfront. | Long riverside paths for cycling, running or simply strolling at sunset. | Four real seasons, from cherry blossoms to colourful fall foliage and festive winters.
washington d c usa.bonus: Time a sunset visit to the Lincoln Memorial, then turn around for a perfectly framed view along the Reflecting Pool towards the Capitol.

gozo malta.desc: Gozo, Malta’s quieter sister island, feels made for unhurried days between sea and countryside. You reach it by ferry and then wander through stone villages, terraced hills and a coastline carved into cliffs, coves and natural pools. Red-sand Ramla Bay, the citadel of Victoria and the prehistoric Ġgantija temples all tell different chapters of the island’s story. Gozo is a great match if you prefer kayaking, snorkelling and long sunset walks to big resorts, and want a base that still feels distinctly local.
gozo malta.highlights: Compact island with dramatic cliffs, sheltered bays and clear turquoise water. | Short ferry hop from Malta, yet with a noticeably slower, rural rhythm. | Excellent snorkelling and diving around Dwejra, the Blue Hole and hidden inlets. | Victoria’s hilltop citadel and UNESCO-listed Ġgantija temples for culture days. | Plenty of walking and coastal paths for couples, friends and active families.
gozo malta.bonus: Head to Dwejra around sunset: rock pools, sea caves and shifting colours make it one of Gozo’s most atmospheric corners.

luberon france.desc: The Luberon, in the heart of Provence, is a patchwork of hilltop villages, vineyards and lavender fields bathed in soft southern light. You follow winding country roads between stone farmhouses and cypress trees, stopping in places like Gordes or Roussillon to wander quiet lanes and sip rosé on shaded terraces. Walking trails cross oak woods, ochre cliffs and gentle valleys where the only sounds are cicadas and church bells. The Luberon is a beautiful choice if you enjoy slow travel, characterful B&Bs and days that drift naturally from market mornings to sunset viewpoints.
luberon france.highlights: String of picture-perfect hilltop villages such as Gordes, Roussillon and Bonnieux. | Summer lavender fields and vineyards creating classic Provençal postcards. | Luberon Regional Nature Park with well-marked hiking and cycling routes. | Lively weekly markets full of cheese, wine, olive oil and local crafts. | Many charming stone farmhouses and boutique stays ideal for couples or friends.
luberon france.bonus: Before dusk, drive up above one of the villages, like Gordes or Saignon, to watch the houses turn golden while the valley falls into shadow.

castelluccio di norcia italy.desc: Castelluccio di Norcia, high in the Apennines of Umbria, overlooks the wide Piano Grande plateau and the peaks of the Monti Sibillini. In late spring and early summer, the fields around the village explode in colourful blooms of lentils, poppies and wildflowers, while the rest of the year offers huge open skies and shifting light. You can hike or cycle across rolling pastures, follow trails towards Monte Vettore or simply drive the scenic bends to admire the panorama. It’s a magical escape if you love quiet landscapes, photography and long days outdoors.
castelluccio di norcia italy.highlights: Sweeping views over the Piano Grande plateau and Monti Sibillini peaks. | Spectacular wildflower bloom around June, with lentil fields turning multicoloured. | Network of hiking and biking trails from gentle walks to longer treks. | Peaceful mountain atmosphere, far from traffic and bright city lights.
castelluccio di norcia italy.bonus: Drive up at sunrise or sunset to watch shadows move across the plateau – the changing colours feel almost like a private light show.

chefchaouen morocco.desc: Chefchaouen, tucked into Morocco’s Rif Mountains, is a small hill town where almost every wall is painted in dreamy shades of blue. As you wander the stepped alleys of the medina, you pass arched doorways, flower‑filled pots and tiny squares where locals linger over mint tea. Cooler mountain air and relaxed rhythms make it an easy place to slow down between busy Moroccan cities, and trails lead from the edge of town towards green valleys and viewpoints. It’s a wonderful stop if you love photography, artisan shops and evenings on a rooftop terrace watching the light fade.
chefchaouen morocco.highlights: Blue‑washed streets and houses that feel like a real‑life movie set. | Compact medina that’s easy to explore at your own relaxed pace. | Cooler mountain climate than the coast, pleasant in spring and autumn. | Short walks to viewpoints and Ras El Ma stream for sunset or picnics.
chefchaouen morocco.bonus: Climb to the Spanish Mosque above town at golden hour – the view of the blue medina framed by mountains is unforgettable.

portland usa.desc: Portland, Oregon balances small‑city friendliness with a creative, slightly quirky energy, set between forested hills and the Willamette River in the Pacific Northwest. You can spend mornings in lush urban parks like Forest Park or the Japanese Garden, then wander into neighbourhoods filled with independent bookstores, coffee roasters and food carts serving every cuisine you can imagine. Craft breweries, bike‑friendly streets and a strong local‑made culture keep things relaxed but never boring. With the Columbia River Gorge and Mount Hood within easy reach, it’s a great base if you want to mix city breaks with outdoor adventures.
portland usa.highlights: Lush parks and gardens within the city, from Forest Park to the Rose Test Garden. | Legendary food‑cart scene and farm‑to‑table restaurants on almost every corner. | Dozens of craft breweries and cosy coffee shops with a local, creative vibe. | Easy day trips to waterfalls in the Columbia River Gorge and Mount Hood trails.
portland usa.bonus: On a rainy evening, duck into Powell’s City of Books and then a nearby brewery – the perfect way to feel Portland like a local.

busan south korea.desc: Busan, South Korea’s lively port city on the south coast, blends wide beaches, colourful hillsides and bright neon streets in one trip‑friendly package. You can spend the morning at Haeundae or Gwangalli Beach, walk coastal paths or visit the cliff‑top temple of Haedong Yonggungsa, then dive into Jagalchi Fish Market for mountains of fresh seafood. Above the harbour, Gamcheon Culture Village adds a maze of painted houses, murals and small galleries. With efficient metro lines, sea‑view cafés and steamy jjimjilbang spas, Busan works just as well for a relaxed seaside break as for a few fast‑paced days of city exploration.
busan south korea.highlights: Long sandy beaches like Haeundae and Gwangalli with easy city access. | Iconic Jagalchi Fish Market for ultra‑fresh seafood and lively local colour. | Gamcheon Culture Village’s steep alleys full of street art and viewpoints. | Coastal temple Haedong Yonggungsa and scenic walks with sea views.
busan south korea.bonus: Ride the Songdo cable car at dusk – watching the city lights switch on above the bay is a simple but memorable Busan moment.

val di funes italia.desc: Val di Funes, a quiet side valley in the Dolomites of South Tyrol, is all about meadows, farmhouses and the dramatic saw‑toothed skyline of the Odle/Geisler peaks. From villages like Santa Maddalena you look straight onto green pastures rising towards pale rock towers that turn pink at sunset. Well‑marked trails such as the Adolf Munkel Path lead through larch forests to alpine huts like Geisleralm, where you can pause for homemade dishes and views. With gentle walks, playgrounds near mountain huts and small family‑run guesthouses, it’s a dream base for hikers, photographers and anyone who prefers quiet landscapes to busy ski resorts.
val di funes italia.highlights: Iconic postcard views of Odle/Geisler peaks behind churches and farmhouses. | Adolf Munkel Trail and other hikes combining forests, pastures and limestone cliffs. | Peaceful valley with limited traffic and mostly small, family‑run guesthouses. | Great in summer and autumn for wildflower meadows or golden larch forests.
val di funes italia.bonus: Stay out until blue hour near Santa Maddalena; the last light on the rock spires above the little church is one of the Dolomites’ most magical scenes.

nikk japan.desc: Nikko, north of Tokyo, wraps you in cedar forests, mountain air and centuries of spiritual history. You wander between lavish shrines and quiet mossy stone lanterns, then escape to the nearby national park with its lakes, waterfalls and steaming onsen. From Toshogu Shrine and the red Shinkyo Bridge to Lake Chuzenji and Kegon Falls, everything feels both scenic and deeply symbolic. Come if you want to mix culture, nature and gentle hikes without straying too far from the city.
nikk japan.highlights: UNESCO shrines and temples hidden among towering cedar forests. | Shinkyo Bridge and atmospheric riverside paths for easy walks. | Lake Chuzenji and Kegon Falls for cool mountain scenery. | Relaxing hot springs and ryokan stays after a day exploring.
nikk japan.bonus: Follow the trail along Kanmangafuchi Abyss at dusk, when the stone Jizo statues and river rapids create a quietly mystical atmosphere.

berchtesgaden germany.desc: Berchtesgaden lies deep in the Bavarian Alps, where sheer rock walls plunge into emerald lakes and tiny villages cling to green slopes. You can cruise across Königssee, ride a cable car for wide‑open views, or follow trails into Berchtesgaden National Park. History is never far away, from the Eagle’s Nest to old salt mines carved under the mountains. It’s a great base if you love mixing alpine scenery, outdoor adventures and a touch of culture in one compact area.
berchtesgaden germany.highlights: Dramatic alpine landscapes with easy access to Berchtesgaden National Park. | Boat trips on Königssee with views of cliffs and St. Bartholomä. | Scenic drives and cable cars to panoramic mountain viewpoints. | Choice of hikes, winter sports and thermal pools in every season.
berchtesgaden germany.bonus: Take an early‑morning boat across Königssee, then hike on to Obersee for mirror‑like reflections of peaks in almost complete silence.

langhe italy.desc: The Langhe, in Piedmont, feels like an endless sea of rolling hills covered in vineyards, hazelnut groves and stone villages. You drive or cycle along crest‑top roads, stopping for tastings of Barolo, Barbaresco and small family wines, then linger over long meals built around local pasta and seasonal truffles. Castles, tiny hilltop towns and slow rural rhythms make each day unhurried. Come if you enjoy food‑focused trips where the landscape, the cellar and the table are all part of the same experience.
langhe italy.highlights: Soft vineyard landscapes recognized as a UNESCO cultural landscape. | Wine routes linking Barolo, La Morra and other hilltop villages. | Excellent seasonal cuisine with white truffles and hazelnut desserts. | Quiet country stays in farmhouses and boutique wine resorts.
langhe italy.bonus: Plan a late‑afternoon walk between two wine villages and watch the sun set over the vines before a relaxed tasting in a family‑run cellar.

loire valley sancerre france.desc: Sancerre sits on a rocky hill above the Loire Valley, surrounded on all sides by neat rows of Sauvignon Blanc vines. In the village you wander cobbled streets, stone houses and small wine bars, with wide views over the river and rolling countryside from the ramparts. Nearby producers open their cellars for tastings, often paired with the local Crottin de Chavignol goat’s cheese. It’s a perfect stop if you enjoy slow days of walks, viewpoints and glasses of crisp white wine far from big‑city noise.
loire valley sancerre france.highlights: Hilltop medieval village overlooking vineyards and the Loire countryside. | Numerous cellars offering Sancerre tastings in a relaxed setting. | Easy walks between Sancerre and neighbouring wine hamlets. | Local goat cheese and seasonal dishes that match the region’s wines.
loire valley sancerre france.bonus: Climb to one of the viewpoints above the village at sunset and watch the last light slide across the patchwork of vineyards down to the Loire.

jeonju south korea.desc: Jeonju, in southwestern Korea, is famous for its Hanok Village where hundreds of traditional wooden houses line narrow lanes. You wander between tiled roofs, teahouses, street‑food stalls and small museums, then climb to nearby viewpoints for a carpet of rooftops beneath the hills. Beyond the historic quarter, the city feels young and creative, with cafés, markets and festivals centred on film, food and culture. It’s a great choice if you want to combine classic Korea – hanbok, temples, bibimbap – with a relaxed, walkable city break.
jeonju south korea.highlights: Large Hanok Village with well‑preserved traditional Korean houses. | Chance to rent hanbok and stroll through atmospheric streets. | Strong food scene, especially Jeonju‑style bibimbap and street snacks. | Easy day‑trip destination from Seoul by high‑speed train or bus.
jeonju south korea.bonus: Stay overnight in a hanok guesthouse and wake up early to explore the alleys before most visitors arrive, when the village is almost silent.

great smoky mountains usa.desc: Straddling the border of North Carolina and Tennessee, the Great Smoky Mountains wrap you in blue‑hazed ridges and deep, forested valleys. You follow winding roads to waterfalls, viewpoints and quiet trailheads that lead into old‑growth woods, mountain balds and wildflower meadows. Historic cabins, gristmills and churches tell the story of early Appalachian communities scattered through the hollows. It’s an inspiring escape if you love varied hikes, scenic drives and the feeling of being in a truly wild national park.
great smoky mountains usa.highlights: Network of well‑marked trails, from gentle creek paths to challenging climbs on the Appalachian Trail. | Scenic roads like Newfound Gap Road and Cades Cove Loop with countless viewpoints. | Lush forests, waterfalls and misty ridges that look different in every season. | Good chances to spot wildlife such as black bears, elk and summer fireflies. | Easy base towns like Gatlinburg or Cherokee with cabins, diners and visitor centers.
great smoky mountains usa.bonus: On a clear evening, drive to Clingmans Dome and walk the short ramp for a sunset that layers the Smokies in endless shades of blue.

transylvania romania.desc: Transylvania, in the heart of Romania, combines wild Carpathian peaks with storybook medieval towns and pastel‑coloured squares. One day you’re hiking above alpine meadows in Piatra Craiului or the Făgăraș Mountains, the next you’re wandering Brașov, Sibiu or Sighișoara between fortified churches and baroque façades. Forests shelter bears and wolves, while hilltop castles like Bran and Corvin keep the region’s legends alive. It’s a great choice if you want a mix of nature, history and atmosphere without the crowds or prices of Western Europe.
transylvania romania.highlights: Carpathian mountain scenery with hiking trails ranging from easy ridge walks to serious multi‑day routes. | Medieval cities such as Brașov, Sibiu and Sighișoara with colourful streets and lively cafés. | Famous castles and fortresses, from Bran’s cliff‑top towers to the Gothic bulk of Corvin. | Traditional villages with wooden gates, haystacks and fortified Saxon churches. | Generally excellent value for money compared with many other European destinations.
transylvania romania.bonus: Join a guided hike in Piatra Craiului National Park to watch sunset over sharp limestone ridges and tiny villages scattered in the valleys.

adirondack mountains usa.desc: The Adirondack Mountains in upstate New York are a huge playground of lakes, forested peaks and quiet small towns. Within the six‑million‑acre Adirondack Park you can paddle across mirror‑calm lakes at sunrise, hike to rocky viewpoints above endless tree cover or cycle quiet backroads between villages. In autumn the hills explode in red and gold, while winter brings snowshoeing, skiing and frozen‑lake adventures around Lake Placid and Saranac Lake. Choose this region if you want the feel of real North American wilderness without straying too far from cosy inns and campgrounds.
adirondack mountains usa.highlights: Vast protected park with hundreds of miles of hiking and paddling routes. | Iconic High Peaks area offering rewarding day hikes with big panoramic views. | Thousands of lakes and ponds ideal for canoeing, kayaking and sunrise photography. | Charming hubs like Lake Placid with outdoor shops, breweries and a laid‑back vibe. | Distinct four‑season appeal, from fiery fall foliage to snowy winter escapes.
adirondack mountains usa.bonus: Plan at least one early‑morning paddle on a still lake: watching the mist lift off the water with the mountains reflected is pure Adirondacks magic.

peak district uk.desc: The Peak District, between Manchester and Sheffield in northern England, is a patchwork of soft green dales, open moorland and gritstone edges. In a single weekend you can follow riverside paths through limestone gorges, stride across windswept plateaus or climb to viewpoints above reservoirs and dry‑stone walls. Villages like Bakewell, Castleton and Edale add stone cottages, cosy pubs and tea rooms to the picture. It’s a brilliant choice if you want big countryside and classic British walks without venturing far from trains, buses and friendly local pubs.
peak district uk.highlights: Britain’s first national park, with a dense network of public footpaths and bridleways. | Contrasting landscapes: gentle White Peak dales and wilder Dark Peak moors and edges. | Characterful villages with traditional pubs, bakeries and riverside beer gardens. | Excellent walking, trail‑running, cycling and rock‑climbing options for all ability levels. | Easy access by train or car from major cities like Manchester, Sheffield and Leeds.
peak district uk.bonus: Follow a circular walk that ends in a village pub garden at golden hour — few things feel more “Peak District” than muddy boots and a locals’ ale.

levi finland.desc: Levi, in Finnish Lapland, is a compact ski village surrounded by snowy fells, quiet forests and wide Arctic skies. In winter you spend your days carving down well‑groomed pistes or gliding along hundreds of kilometres of cross‑country tracks, then warm up in saunas, cafés and slope‑side bars. At night the sky often turns into a stage for the northern lights, especially when you head a little away from the village lights. It’s an ideal base if you want a mix of reliable snow, easy‑to‑reach skiing and those once‑in‑a‑lifetime Lapland experiences.
levi finland.highlights: Finland’s largest ski resort, with varied pistes for beginners, families and confident skiers. | Extensive cross‑country skiing network plus snowshoe trails through silent forests. | Good chances to see the aurora borealis thanks to Levi’s location above the Arctic Circle. | Plenty of winter activities beyond skiing: snowmobiles, husky and reindeer safaris, ice‑fishing. | Convenient access via Kittilä Airport and a compact village you can mostly explore on foot.
levi finland.bonus: Book at least one night in an aurora cabin or glass‑roofed igloo: watching the northern lights from bed is a very Levi kind of luxury.

troms norway.desc: Tromsø, in northern Norway, lies between steep mountains and cold fjords well above the Arctic Circle. In winter you can chase the northern lights, join husky or reindeer sled rides and then warm up in cosy cafés, museums and lively bars. When the snow melts, the islands and trails around Tromsø invite you to hike, kayak and watch the midnight sun glowing over the sea. Choose this Arctic city if you want wild scenery, real Nordic culture and comfortable hotels in one place.
troms norway.highlights: High chance of seeing the northern lights between September and early April. | Compact Arctic city with cafés, museums, bars and a friendly local vibe. | Easy access to fjords, islands and mountains for guided winter or summer tours. | Husky and reindeer excursions that introduce you to Sámi stories and traditions.
troms norway.bonus: Ride the Fjellheisen cable car one clear evening to see Tromsø, the fjords and, with luck, curtains of aurora shimmering above you.

charlevoix canada.desc: Along the north shore of the St. Lawrence River in Québec, Charlevoix combines dramatic mountains, wide river views and postcard villages. You can follow scenic roads, hike in nearby national parks, ski the steep slopes in winter or ride a snowmobile across quiet white valleys before relaxing in a cosy inn. In the warmer months, whale-watching cruises, cycling routes and farmers’ markets showcase the region’s nature and flavours. Charlevoix is perfect if you love outdoor adventure but also appreciate good food, art galleries and tranquil evenings.
charlevoix canada.highlights: Spectacular river and mountain landscapes just a few hours from Québec City. | Year-round outdoor activities including hiking, biking, skiing and snowmobiling. | Charming inns and lodges serving local cheeses, ciders and creative Québec cuisine. | Excellent base for whale-watching cruises on the St. Lawrence River.
charlevoix canada.bonus: Drive the Route du Fleuve at sunset and stop at viewpoints above Baie-Saint-Paul or La Malbaie to watch the light change over the river and hills.

sapporo japan.desc: Sapporo, the capital of Hokkaido, blends a modern Japanese city with snowy winters and wide parks. In February the famous Sapporo Snow Festival fills Odori Park with giant ice and snow sculptures, food stalls and illuminations, while nearby mountains offer reliable powder for skiing and snowboarding. The rest of the year you can taste miso ramen and local beer, stroll along tree-lined boulevards and use Sapporo as a base to explore hot-spring towns and national parks. It is ideal if you want urban energy, winter fun and easy access to nature in one trip.
sapporo japan.highlights: Lively northern city with broad streets, parks and a relaxed atmosphere. | World-renowned Sapporo Snow Festival with impressive sculptures and night lights. | Easy day trips to ski resorts, hot springs and scenic Hokkaido countryside. | Strong food scene with miso ramen, fresh seafood and local craft beer.
sapporo japan.bonus: Visit the Snow Festival after dark, then warm up in a nearby izakaya with steaming ramen and a glass of locally brewed beer.

jasper canada.desc: Jasper, in Alberta’s Jasper National Park, places you in the heart of the Canadian Rockies with peaks, forests and turquoise lakes all around. From the town you can drive to viewpoints, waterfalls and canyons, paddle on calm lakes or ride the Jasper SkyTram for wide alpine views, while in winter the mountains turn into a quiet world of snow and ice. Wildlife such as elk and maybe even bears are often seen along the roads. Jasper suits you if you want big mountain scenery, easy day hikes and a relaxed base rather than a crowded resort town.
jasper canada.highlights: Set inside the largest national park in the Canadian Rockies with vast wilderness. | Scenic drives to lakes, canyons and viewpoints like Maligne Lake and Athabasca Falls. | Plenty of easy to moderate trails starting close to town for day hikes. | Good chances to spot wildlife such as elk, bighorn sheep and deer.
jasper canada.bonus: Take an evening stroll along the shore of Pyramid Lake or Lac Beauvert to see the mountains turn pink and, on clear nights, a sky full of stars.

andorra la vella andorra.desc: Andorra la Vella, the tiny capital of Andorra, sits high in the Pyrenees surrounded by steep mountains. The town mixes old stone streets and modern shopping avenues where duty-free boutiques, outdoor stores and electronics line Meritxell Avenue, while nearby slopes give access to the Grandvalira and Pal-Arinsal ski areas. In summer you can follow trails into quiet valleys or combine hikes with spa time at Caldea. Choose Andorra la Vella if you like the idea of a compact city base with mountain scenery, easy skiing and plenty of shopping and wellness options.
andorra la vella andorra.highlights: Mountain capital set at high altitude in the heart of the Pyrenees. | Quick access by bus or car to major Andorran ski resorts in winter. | Long shopping streets with duty-free fashion, sports gear and electronics. | Good mix of traditional old town, modern cafés and large thermal spa centres.
andorra la vella andorra.bonus: Spend a day on the slopes, then soak in the warm pools of Caldea in the evening while you watch the lights of Andorra la Vella reflected on the surrounding peaks.

innsbruck austria.desc: Nestled between towering Alpine peaks, Innsbruck, Austria blends historic charm with serious mountain energy. In a few minutes you can ride from the colorful houses along the River Inn up to panoramic viewpoints on the Nordkette, with ski slopes, hiking trails and mountain huts right at the edge of the city. The medieval Old Town, the Golden Roof and elegant imperial palaces add a royal touch to your strolls. Ideal if you want a trip that mixes outdoor adventure, winter sports and relaxed café culture in one compact place.
innsbruck austria.highlights: Mountain lifts from the centre straight to Alpine viewpoints and ski areas. | Atmospheric Old Town with the Golden Roof and colourful riverside facades. | Wide choice of winter sports: skiing, snowboarding, tobogganing and winter hiking. | Easy to explore on foot, with cosy cafés and traditional Tyrolean restaurants. | Christmas markets and winter events that make the city feel like a snow globe.
innsbruck austria.bonus: Take the cable car at sunset: watching the city lights flicker beneath snowy peaks is one of the most memorable views in the Austrian Alps.

riga latvia.desc: On the banks of the Daugava River, Riga, Latvia combines a medieval Old Town with one of Europe’s richest Art Nouveau districts. Cobbled lanes lead to church spires, cosy cafés and market halls, while just outside the centre whole streets are lined with ornate façades from the early 1900s. In summer the long evenings fill the terraces and riverfront with life; in winter lanterns and snow add a storybook feel. It’s a great choice if you like culture‑packed city breaks with a relaxed, creative atmosphere.
riga latvia.highlights: UNESCO‑listed Old Town full of churches, towers and winding cobbled streets. | Famous Art Nouveau quarter with spectacular house façades and small museums. | Lively cafés, bars and restaurants that stay friendly and affordable by European standards. | Easy day trips to forests, beaches and coastal towns along the Baltic Sea. | Compact city centre that’s walkable and well connected by cheap public transport.
riga latvia.bonus: Join a guided walk through the Art Nouveau streets at golden hour: the carved faces and balconies glow in the soft Baltic light.

vilnius lithuania.desc: Vilnius, Lithuania’s green and slightly bohemian capital, has one of the largest Baroque Old Towns in Europe and a relaxed, lived‑in feel. Church towers, quiet courtyards and university buildings hide between narrow streets, while creative districts and street art give the city a youthful twist. From Gediminas Hill you look out over red‑tiled roofs, rivers and surrounding forests, all surprisingly close to the centre. It’s a smart pick if you want a city break full of history and character but without the crowds of more obvious capitals.
vilnius lithuania.highlights: UNESCO‑listed Old Town with baroque churches, courtyards and atmospheric alleys. | Laid‑back cafés, wine bars and craft beer spots popular with locals and students. | Creative neighbourhoods with murals, galleries and small independent shops. | Green hills, riverside paths and nearby forests ideal for easy walks and picnics. | Generally lower prices than in many Western European capitals, useful for longer stays.
vilnius lithuania.bonus: Climb up to Gediminas Tower at sunset: the view over the Old Town domes and forests glowing in golden light is unforgettable.

kiruna sweden.desc: In the far north of Sweden, Kiruna sits above the Arctic Circle surrounded by forests, frozen lakes and wide tundra plains. In winter the long nights bring frequent northern lights displays, dog‑sled tours and snowmobile safaris, while nearby Jukkasjärvi is home to the world‑famous Icehotel built from ice and snow each year. In summer the midnight sun turns hikes and canoe trips into endless golden evenings. Kiruna suits adventurous travellers who dream of Arctic landscapes, star‑filled skies and learning more about Sámi culture in a real working town.
kiruna sweden.highlights: Excellent base for chasing the northern lights from September to March. | Access to the original Icehotel in nearby Jukkasjärvi with unique ice rooms. | Wide choice of winter activities: dog sledding, snowmobiling, snowshoe hikes and reindeer visits. | Midnight sun in summer, with easy trails, lakes and fells to explore day and night. | Chance to learn about Sámi traditions and see how an Arctic mining town is being relocated.
kiruna sweden.bonus: Book a night in an ice room and step outside after midnight: watching the aurora dance above a completely silent snowy landscape feels almost unreal.

laax switzerland.desc: Laax, in the Swiss canton of Graubünden, is part of the Flims Laax Falera ski area and feels purpose‑built for people who love the mountains in every season. In winter you get a large, high‑altitude resort with snow‑sure slopes, long runs and some of Europe’s most famous freestyle parks, served by modern lifts. Summer brings flowy bike trails, hiking routes to turquoise lakes and family‑friendly adventures. It’s an ideal base if you want an active holiday with a sporty, youthful vibe rather than a purely traditional village.
laax switzerland.highlights: Around 170–200 kilometres of pistes plus extra ski routes across linked Flims Laax Falera area. | Snow‑reliable terrain, with much of the ski area above 2,000 metres. | Renowned snowparks and halfpipes that attract freestyle skiers and snowboarders from all over. | Good mix of blue, red and black runs, plus off‑piste options when conditions allow. | In summer, extensive biking and hiking network with lakes, viewpoints and fun activities for families.
laax switzerland.bonus: On a clear day take the lift up towards the glacier plateau: the wide‑open views over the Alps while you carve or hike are seriously impressive.

cervinia italia.desc: High above the Aosta Valley, Cervinia unfolds beneath the striking pyramid of the Matterhorn on the Italian–Swiss border. Here you glide along wide, high-altitude slopes that roll for kilometres, linking Italy with the lifts and pistes of Zermatt in one of the Alps’ largest ski areas. Reliable snow cover and a sunny, open bowl mean long days on beautifully groomed runs, from gentle blues for cruisers to steeper sections for stronger legs. Cervinia is ideal if you love big mountain scenery, long descents and a relaxed Italian après-ski scene at the end of the day.
cervinia italia.highlights: Snow-sure, high-altitude slopes beneath the iconic Matterhorn. | Long, forgiving runs perfect for intermediate skiers and boarders. | Direct lift connections with Zermatt for cross-border ski days. | Sunny mountain bowl with wide-open panoramic views. | Relaxed village atmosphere with Italian food and laid-back après-ski.
cervinia italia.bonus: Ride the cable car to Plateau Rosa, ski over for lunch on the Swiss side, then glide back to Italy with sunset views of the Matterhorn.

rusutsu japan.desc: On Hokkaido’s western slopes, Rusutsu is a laid-back resort wrapped in deep, dry Japanese powder. You weave between perfectly spaced trees and open groomers that flow off three connected peaks, with views towards Lake Tōya and Mount Yōtei on clear days. Compared with busier Niseko, the pistes here feel quieter and more spacious, and the resort hotels bundle together lifts, restaurants, kids’ areas and even indoor amusements. It’s a great place to discover “Japow” for the first time, especially if you’re travelling with family or a small group of friends.
rusutsu japan.highlights: Renowned Hokkaido powder snow on and between the trees. | Quieter slopes than larger Japanese resorts, with plenty of space. | Family-friendly services, kids’ parks and excellent ski schools. | Onsen and sauna options to warm up after a cold powder day. | Modern hotels with easy ski-in/ski-out style convenience.
rusutsu japan.bonus: Finish your day floating through the last soft tree run, then soak in an outdoor onsen while fat snowflakes fall silently into the steam around you.

big white canada.desc: Set in the mountains above Kelowna in British Columbia, Big White is a true ski‑in, ski‑out village built for people who want to spend all day on snow. You move easily between compact accommodation, lifts and restaurants, and then straight onto long groomers, gentle learning slopes and playful tree runs covered in the resort’s famous “champagne powder”. Night skiing, tubing, skating and other off‑slope activities keep the energy going after the lifts close. Big White is a favourite if you’re travelling with kids or mixed‑ability friends and want everything within walking distance.
big white canada.highlights: One of Canada’s most ski‑in, ski‑out friendly resort villages. | Reliable dry powder snow with plenty of groomed runs and glades. | Lots of family‑focused activities, from tubing to skating and sleigh rides. | Extensive night skiing and a lively, compact village core. | Easy access from Kelowna with shuttles up to the mountain.
big white canada.bonus: Stay out for the night skiing session, then lace up your skates on the huge outdoor rink and finish with hot chocolate in the glowing village.

avoriaz france.desc: Perched on a clifftop in the French Alps, Avoriaz is a wooden, car‑free resort where you slide everywhere on skis or on foot. The buildings follow the steep rock faces and open directly onto the snow, giving instant access to the vast Portes du Soleil ski area that links France and Switzerland. Families love the easy ski‑in/ski‑out feel, the playful snow parks and the tropical Aquariaz water park, while advanced riders can head out towards high alpine bowls and cross‑border circuits. The atmosphere is lively yet compact, ideal if you want everything close at hand without using a car all week.
avoriaz france.highlights: Completely pedestrian, car‑free resort with true ski‑in/ski‑out living. | Direct gateway to the huge Portes du Soleil cross‑border ski domain. | Striking wooden architecture perched dramatically above the cliffs. | Family‑friendly vibe with snow parks, kids’ areas and Aquariaz. | Lively après‑ski and restaurants clustered in a walkable village.
avoriaz france.bonus: Book an evening ride in a horse‑drawn sleigh through the snowy, car‑free streets to watch the wooden façades glow in the mountain twilight.

park city usa.desc: Nestled in Utah’s Wasatch Range, Park City combines the scale of the largest ski resort in the United States with the charm of a historic mountain town. You can explore 7,300 acres of terrain across bowls, groomers, glades and terrain parks, then quite literally ski down to buzzing Main Street for shops, galleries and western‑style restaurants. Two main base areas, Mountain Village and Canyons Village, offer plenty of lodging, ski schools and family‑friendly services, all just about 35 minutes from Salt Lake City International Airport. It’s an ideal choice if you want big‑mountain skiing without giving up lively nights and easy access.
park city usa.highlights: 7,300 acres of varied terrain, from gentle groomers to steep bowls. | Ski access to historic Main Street lined with shops and restaurants. | Short transfer from Salt Lake City airport, easy for long weekends. | Multiple villages with lodging, ski schools and services for families. | Vibrant après‑ski scene with bars, dining and cultural events in town.
park city usa.bonus: Spend the day exploring high alpine bowls, then ski straight towards Main Street, unclip by the sidewalks and head into town for an evening of galleries and cocktails.

hakuba valley japan.desc: Hakuba Valley, tucked into Japan’s Northern Alps near Nagano, links several ski resorts framed by dramatic, snow-covered peaks. Winter here means metres of light powder, long groomed runs and hidden tree lines where you can taste the famous “Japow”. Villages at the base mix steaming onsen, cosy lodges and lively izakaya, so your evenings feel as memorable as your days on the mountain. Choose Hakuba Valley if you want big-mountain terrain, reliable snow and a first encounter with Japanese mountain culture.
hakuba valley japan.highlights: Deep, reliable powder snow typical of Japan’s high mountain winters. | Several interlinked resorts with terrain for beginners, cruisers and experts. | Tree runs and sidecountry bowls for adventurous skiers and snowboarders. | Traditional villages, onsen baths and izakaya for atmospheric après-ski. | Easy rail access from Tokyo via Nagano and convenient local shuttles.
hakuba valley japan.bonus: End the day soaking in an open-air onsen while snowflakes fall around you, then stroll past lantern-lit streets back to your ryokan or lodge.

baqueira beret spain.desc: Baqueira Beret lies high in the Val d’Aran, in the heart of the Spanish Pyrenees. Wide, north-facing slopes, modern lifts and long descents create relaxed days on reliably good snow. Between runs you can slip down to stone villages for tapas, local Aranese dishes and a glass of wine by the fire. Baqueira Beret is ideal if you love varied pistes, a friendly Spanish atmosphere and a ski holiday that mixes strong skiing with long, sociable evenings.
baqueira beret spain.highlights: Large, well-groomed ski area with plenty of blue and red runs. | North-facing orientation that helps keep the snow cold and consistent. | Good mix of family facilities, ski schools and beginner-friendly zones. | Charming Val d’Aran villages with tapas bars and mountain restaurants. | Convenient access from Barcelona or Toulouse via scenic mountain roads.
baqueira beret spain.bonus: On a sunny day, ski the full circuit across Baqueira, Beret and Bonaigua, then stop on a high terrace for tapas in the middle of the snowy peaks.

val thorens france.desc: Val Thorens sits at 2,300 metres in the French Alps, the highest ski village in Europe. From most doorsteps you slide straight onto wide, high-altitude pistes that usually stay snowy from early winter into spring. Ultra-modern lifts link into the vast Three Valleys area, so every day can be a new circuit. With lively bars, restaurants and wellness centres packed into a compact, car-free resort, Val Thorens suits travellers who want snow-sure skiing, convenience and a buzzing, international atmosphere.
val thorens france.highlights: Ski-in, ski-out village with pistes starting just outside most accommodation. | Europe’s highest resort, offering a long and generally reliable ski season. | Direct access to over 600 km of slopes in Les 3 Vallées ski area. | Modern lifts, snowparks and varied terrain for all levels of skier and rider. | Busy après-ski, spas and non-ski activities such as tobogganing and zip-lines.
val thorens france.bonus: Take the lift up to Cime Caron for a 360° panorama of jagged Alpine peaks before carving one of the classic long descents back towards the village.

cardrona new zealand.desc: Cardrona Alpine Resort rises above a broad valley between Wānaka and Queenstown on New Zealand’s South Island. In the southern winter you’ll find long, rolling pistes, dedicated beginner areas and terrain parks where international athletes come to train. When the snow retreats, the same slopes turn into a playground for mountain biking, hiking and mountain carting under big southern skies. Cardrona is a relaxed, friendly base if you want to combine a road trip of lakes and vineyards with flexible ski or bike days.
cardrona new zealand.highlights: New Zealand’s largest accessible ski area with varied pistes for all levels. | Renowned terrain parks that attract freestyle skiers and snowboarders worldwide. | Family-focused facilities including beginner zones, lessons and laid-back cafés. | Summer bike park with lift-accessed downhill trails and mountain carting. | Conveniently located between Wānaka and Queenstown for wider South Island exploring.
cardrona new zealand.bonus: Stay for sunset on a clear evening and watch the Southern Alps glow orange while the lakes far below slowly disappear into the dusk.

st anton am arlberg austria.desc: St. Anton am Arlberg is a classic Tyrolean village with serious ski credentials. Steep pistes, deep-snow routes and the vast linked Ski Arlberg area turn each day into a challenge for confident skiers and riders. Down in the village, a car-free main street and famously lively après-ski bars create a festive mountain-town feel. St. Anton is a great match if you dream of big vertical, long off-piste lines and evenings that continue well after the last lift has closed.
st anton am arlberg austria.highlights: Direct access to the huge Ski Arlberg area with extensive pistes. | Renowned off-piste terrain and freeride routes for advanced skiers and snowboarders. | Traditional Tyrolean village character with a pleasant pedestrian centre. | Legendary après-ski scene featuring live music, dancing and bustling mountain bars. | Ski schools and guiding services to help you explore steeper slopes safely.
st anton am arlberg austria.bonus: On a bluebird day, hire a guide to link high runs from Valluga with quieter Arlberg valleys, then refuel with hearty Tyrolean dishes back in the village.

tignes france.desc: Tignes sits high in the French Alps, a bold, modern resort wrapped around a frozen lake and dramatic peaks. From early winter to late spring you ski long, snow‑sure slopes that link with neighbouring Val d’Isère, giving you hundreds of kilometres of varied terrain. Glacier runs, wide cruising pistes and playful snowparks mean every level finds its rhythm here, from confident improvers to thrill‑seeking freeriders. With ski‑in/ski‑out accommodation, buzzing bars and plenty of indoor activities, it’s ideal if you want an action‑packed mountain holiday with hardly a dull moment.
tignes france.highlights: High‑altitude slopes with a long, reliable winter season. | Linked ski area with Val d’Isère for huge daily mileage. | Glacier skiing on Grande Motte and wide carving pistes. | Ski‑in/ski‑out stays and lively après‑ski by the frozen lake.
tignes france.bonus: Ride the funicular to the Grande Motte glacier for early‑morning turns above a sea of peaks, then carve the long La Sache run back down.

saas fee switzerland.desc: Saas‑Fee is a car‑free village high in the Swiss Valais, wrapped in glaciers and more than a dozen 4,000‑metre peaks. Wooden barns and narrow lanes give it a storybook charm, while the surrounding slopes offer everything from gentle beginner areas to long red runs and freestyle parks. You can ski well into spring on the glacier and swap skis for winter hiking trails, toboggan runs or ice‑climbing adventures. It’s a dream base if you love crisp mountain air, quiet evenings and big alpine scenery without the traffic.
saas fee switzerland.highlights: Car‑free village with traditional chalets and peaceful streets. | High, glacier‑fed ski area with very reliable snow. | Varied slopes plus winter hiking, sledging and ice adventures. | Panoramic lifts with views of multiple 4,000‑metre summits.
saas fee switzerland.bonus: Take the underground funicular up to Mittelallalin for a revolving‑restaurant lunch above the glaciers and a walk through the impressive ice pavilion.

grindelwald switzerland.desc: Grindelwald lies in the Bernese Oberland at the foot of the famous Eiger North Face, where green alpine pastures meet dramatic rock walls and glaciers. In winter you carve across the Jungfrau ski region, linking slopes above Grindelwald and Kleine Scheidegg with runs that look straight onto the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau. Summer brings a huge network of hiking and biking trails, from gentle valley walks to the legendary Eiger Trail. It’s a great base if you like mixing big mountain scenery with cosy village life and easy access by mountain trains.
grindelwald switzerland.highlights: Spectacular views of the Eiger and surrounding peaks. | Direct access to the Jungfrau ski region and sledging runs. | Extensive summer hiking and biking, including the Eiger Trail. | Mountain railways and gondolas for effortless high‑alpine viewpoints.
grindelwald switzerland.bonus: Take the train up to Jungfraujoch or the gondola to First and walk the cliff‑side platform for a vertigo‑inducing panorama over glaciers and valleys.

vail usa.desc: Vail spreads along a wide valley in the Colorado Rockies, a huge ski playground backed by forested peaks and open bowls. On more than 5,000 acres of terrain you can glide down groomed runs, explore the legendary Back Bowls on powder days or head to Blue Sky Basin for a wilder feel. Vail Village itself has a charming, European‑inspired look with cobbled walkways, boutiques and an impressive dining scene. It’s a strong choice if you want big‑mountain skiing combined with comfortable hotels, lively après‑ski and plenty to do off the slopes.
vail usa.highlights: One of Colorado’s largest ski areas with vast terrain variety. | Iconic Back Bowls offering wide, open powder slopes. | Alpine‑style Vail Village with shops, galleries and cosy bars. | Excellent dining, from casual spots to refined gourmet venues.
vail usa.bonus: Ski the Back Bowls in the morning, then unwind with craft cocktails and mountain views on a heated patio in Vail Village as the sun drops behind the Rockies.

ischgl austria.desc: Ischgl sits in Austria’s Paznaun valley, a lively resort at the heart of the Silvretta Arena ski area that stretches across the border into Switzerland. High‑altitude slopes and modern lifts give you long, snow‑sure runs from November into spring, with everything from wide motorway pistes to steeper routes and freeride options. In the village, traditional Tyrolean roofs mix with trendy bars, clubs and concerts that have made Ischgl famous for its nightlife. Choose it if you want serious skiing by day and a social, party‑flavoured atmosphere once the lifts close.
