ischgl austria.highlights: Cross‑border Silvretta Arena linking Ischgl with Samnaun. | Snow‑sure pistes reaching nearly 2,900 metres in altitude. | Modern lift system and a wide choice of runs for all levels. | Renowned après‑ski scene with bars, live music and big events.
ischgl austria.bonus: Spend a day skiing over to duty‑free Samnaun for lunch, then return to Ischgl at sunset for open‑air drinks and mountain views in the pedestrian centre.

furano japan.desc: Furano, in the heart of Hokkaido, shifts with the seasons from a snow-filled ski town to rolling hills covered in lavender and patchwork flower fields. In winter you ride long, well-groomed runs with views of the Tokachi Mountains and famously light powder. When the snow melts, country roads become scenic cycling routes and farm cafés serve local cheese, melons and wine. It’s a great choice if you enjoy mixing outdoor adventure with quiet evenings in a genuinely Japanese countryside atmosphere.
furano japan.highlights: Snowy ski slopes with light, dry Hokkaido powder. | Summer lavender fields and colorful flower farms. | Easy day trips to nearby hot springs and viewpoints. | Family-friendly workshops at the Furano Cheese Factory. | Local wine, sweets and melon treats to sample.
furano japan.bonus: Take the train or a rental bike out to the lavender farms at golden hour and watch the fields fade from purple to pastel under the summer sky.

madonna di campiglio italy.desc: Madonna di Campiglio, tucked between the peaks of the Brenta Dolomites, is a stylish mountain town where skiing and Italian lifestyle go hand in hand. Over 150 kilometres of linked slopes and modern lifts let you ski from valley to valley, from wide cruising runs to steeper descents for experts. Off the snow you stroll through a pedestrian centre filled with cafés, boutiques and pastry shops, or escape on winter walks and cross-country trails in the surrounding forests. It’s a great fit if you love combining serious skiing with cosy evenings and a touch of glamour.
madonna di campiglio italy.highlights: Extensive, interconnected ski area with varied difficulty. | Spectacular Dolomite scenery in every direction. | Lively pedestrian centre with shops, bars and restaurants. | Good options for families, couples and groups of friends. | Mountain huts serving hearty Trentino cuisine on the slopes.
madonna di campiglio italy.bonus: Take an early lift to a panoramic terrace above the town and watch the first light turn the Brenta Dolomites pink before your ski day even begins.

bormio italy.desc: Bormio, in the upper Valtellina, combines a historic alpine village, serious skiing and some of the most famous thermal baths in the Alps. From the slopes you look straight onto the Stelvio National Park, with long descents that include the legendary World Cup downhill run. After a day on snow or hiking trails, you soak in outdoor pools fed by natural hot springs while the peaks turn orange at sunset. Narrow streets, stone houses and small wine bars make the evenings feel intimate and relaxed, especially if you like good food and a slower rhythm.
bormio italy.highlights: Challenging and scenic runs including the Stelvio downhill. | Natural hot springs and modern thermal centres in town. | Access to Stelvio National Park for year-round activities. | Family-friendly areas with fun zones and ski schools. | Characterful old town with local wine and hearty cuisine.
bormio italy.bonus: End one of your ski days with a night visit to the historic thermal baths and float in warm water while watching the cold steam rise into the mountain air.

portillo chile.desc: Portillo, high in the Chilean Andes near the border with Argentina, is a compact ski resort built around one iconic yellow hotel and the deep-blue Lake of the Inca. The slopes rise steeply above the water, offering challenging lines for confident skiers as well as groomed runs with unforgettable views. With no sprawling village, everyone eats, relaxes and socialises in the same few spaces, creating a friendly, almost club-like atmosphere. If you dream of South American winter, dramatic peaks and plenty of time on snow rather than in lift queues, Portillo is hard to beat.
portillo chile.highlights: High-altitude skiing with reliable Andean snow. | Unique setting above the emerald Lake of the Inca. | Intimate, all-in-one resort with ski-in/ski-out hotel. | Steeper terrain and famous off-piste for advanced skiers. | Relaxed social scene with activities beyond the slopes.
portillo chile.bonus: On a clear afternoon, take a break from skiing and walk to the lake shore to photograph the mountains mirrored in the still surface of Laguna del Inca.

inca trail peru.desc: The Inca Trail in Peru is a multi-day trekking route that leads you from the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu along stone paths laid by the Incas. Over several days you climb high passes, sleep in mountain camps and cross cloud forests where orchids cling to the rock and mist drifts through ancient terraces. Along the way you explore lesser-known ruins before reaching the Sun Gate for that first dramatic view of the citadel at sunrise. It’s a demanding adventure, best if you enjoy long days on the trail and the feeling of walking through living history.
inca trail peru.highlights: Classic four-day trek ending at Machu Picchu’s Sun Gate. | Combination of high passes, cloud forest and river valleys. | Numerous Inca archaeological sites only accessible on foot. | Camps under starry Andean skies with support teams. | Strict permit system that limits numbers on the trail.
inca trail peru.bonus: Time your trek to arrive at Inti Punku at dawn and watch Machu Picchu slowly emerge from the morning mist as the sun hits the surrounding peaks.

laugavegur islanda.desc: On Iceland's Laugavegur Trail you walk from the steaming valleys of Landmannalaugar to the green birch forests of Þórsmörk. Along the way you cross black‑sand plains, colourful rhyolite mountains, icy rivers and stretches of old lava that make every stage feel different. Simple mountain huts and campsites keep you close to the elements without giving up all comfort. Summer days are long and the weather can swing quickly, adding drama to the sky. It’s a route for hikers who love raw landscapes, hot springs and a real sense of remoteness.
laugavegur islanda.highlights: Multi-day trek linking Landmannalaugar and Þórsmörk across Icelandic highlands. | Constantly changing scenery: rhyolite peaks, lava fields and black deserts. | Mountain huts spaced for manageable stages with a wilderness atmosphere. | Natural hot springs to soak tired legs before or after the hike.
laugavegur islanda.bonus: Slip into the geothermal pools of Landmannalaugar after a long day, watching pastel Icelandic light linger on the surrounding mountains.

annapurna circuit nepal.desc: Alta Via 1 threads its way across the Dolomites, from the turquoise shores of Lago di Braies to the forests near Belluno. Each day you follow well-marked paths beneath sheer limestone towers, crossing high passes, alpine meadows and occasional wartime tunnels carved in the rock. At night you reach cosy mountain rifugi where you share long wooden tables, local dishes and big views with other hikers. In summer the air is clear and the wildflowers are out, making this route ideal if you enjoy moderate but steady days in spectacular mountains.
annapurna circuit nepal.highlights: Classic hut-to-hut traverse across the Dolomites from north to south. | Combination of balcony paths, high passes and gentle alpine meadows. | Characterful rifugi with hot showers, hearty food and sunrise terrace views. | Flexible stages so you can adapt the itinerary to your pace and time.
annapurna circuit nepal.bonus: Set your alarm early in a high rifugio to watch alpenglow turn peaks like Lagazuoi and Civetta a soft pink above the valleys.

mount meru tanzania.desc: Mount Meru rises like a broken volcano above Arusha National Park, giving you a serious summit without the crowds of Kilimanjaro. Over three to four days you climb from lush forest full of colobus monkeys and giraffes to open moorland and a narrow crater ridge that feels thrillingly exposed. Nights are spent in simple mountain huts, so you carry less weight and still wake up high above the plains. The final push to 4,562 metres rewards you with views over Meru’s ash cone and, on clear mornings, the distant snowy silhouette of Kilimanjaro.
mount meru tanzania.highlights: High-altitude summit trek that is quieter and shorter than Kilimanjaro. | Wildlife on the lower slopes, with giraffes and monkeys in Arusha National Park. | Comfortable huts instead of tents, making logistics and packing much easier. | Dramatic ridge walk at sunrise with vast views into the crater and beyond.
mount meru tanzania.bonus: Plan your climb in the dry season and watch the first light hit Meru’s crater while Kilimanjaro floats on the horizon above a sea of clouds.

camino de santiago spain.desc: The Camino de Santiago in Spain is more than a single trail; it is a whole network of pilgrimage routes that all end at the cathedral in Santiago de Compostela. Day after day you follow yellow arrows through stone villages, vineyards, rolling plains and occasional mountain passes, walking at your own rhythm. Simple albergues and guesthouses keep costs low and evenings social, with shared meals and stories from all over the world. Whether you walk one week or an entire month, this is a journey for travellers who value slow days, reflection and the friendships that grow along the way.
camino de santiago spain.highlights: Multiple route options, from coastal ways to the classic Camino Francés. | Well-marked paths with frequent villages, cafés and pilgrim services. | Budget-friendly albergues and set menus ideal for long-distance walkers. | Strong sense of community, meeting people of all ages and backgrounds.
camino de santiago spain.bonus: Try to arrive for a pilgrim mass in Santiago and feel the emotion when hundreds of tired boots and backpacks finally come to rest inside the cathedral.

torres del paine w trek cile.desc: The W Trek in Torres del Paine, in Chilean Patagonia, links three of the park’s most spectacular valleys in one multi-day hike. You follow a W‑shaped route between turquoise lakes and open steppe, then turn up side valleys towards Grey Glacier, the hanging glaciers of the French Valley and the granite spires that give the park its name. Nights are spent in refugios or campsites, where hot meals and a roof or tent are waiting after long days on the trail. Changeable Patagonian weather brings fast-moving clouds, rainbows and strong winds, making this trek unforgettable for hikers who love raw, dramatic scenery.
torres del paine w trek cile.highlights: Classic W-shaped itinerary visiting Grey Glacier, the French Valley and Base Torres. | Mix of daypacks and fixed overnights in refugios, campgrounds or eco-domes. | Constant views of turquoise lakes, hanging glaciers and sheer granite towers. | Well-organised routes and boat transfers while still feeling deep in Patagonia.
torres del paine w trek cile.bonus: Leave early for the hike to Base Torres and watch the first sunlight turn the three granite towers fiery orange while the lagoon below remains in shadow.

annapurna base camp nepal.desc: Annapurna Base Camp in Nepal leads you deep into a natural amphitheatre of ice and rock, surrounded by some of the highest peaks in the Himalayas. Over several days you hike from terraced villages and lush rhododendron forests up to the high-altitude sanctuary, sleeping in simple teahouses and sharing hot meals with other trekkers. Clear autumn and spring days reveal Fishtail, Annapurna I and a crown of snowy summits glowing above you. It is a rewarding adventure if you love long hikes, changing landscapes and waking up with mountains at your doorstep.
annapurna base camp nepal.highlights: Multi-day Himalayan trek into the heart of the Annapurna Sanctuary. | Teahouse accommodation every night, with hot meals and social atmosphere. | Landscapes shifting from rice terraces and forests to glaciers and moraines. | Best in spring and autumn, when skies are clearer and views are at their sharpest. | Sunrise and sunset light turning the surrounding 8,000-metre peaks golden.
annapurna base camp nepal.bonus: Wake up before dawn at base camp to watch the first pink light hit the peaks in silence, broken only by prayer flags snapping in the wind.

fish river canyon namibia.desc: Fish River Canyon in southern Namibia feels like standing on the edge of a cracked desert planet, with the river carving deep curves through burnt‑orange rock. From viewpoints near Hobas you look down into a maze of cliffs and dry terraces, while experienced hikers can follow the multi‑day canyon trail to Ai‑Ais when conditions allow. Days are filled with heat, silence and wide horizons, nights with an unreal blanket of stars. It is a remote adventure if you love big landscapes, rough tracks and the feeling of being very far from cities.
fish river canyon namibia.highlights: One of Africa’s largest canyons, up to hundreds of metres deep and 160 kilometres long. | Panoramic viewpoints along the rim with sweeping sunset and sunrise vistas. | Legendary multi‑day hiking trail through the canyon for fit, self‑sufficient trekkers. | Wild desert environment with little light pollution and spectacular night skies. | Combination of viewpoints, short walks and longer treks to match your energy level.
fish river canyon namibia.bonus: Time your visit for late afternoon at Hobas viewpoint to watch the canyon slowly change from gold to deep purple as the sun sinks below the plateau.

snowdonia llanberis path wales uk.desc: The Llanberis Path in Snowdonia takes you from the village of Llanberis all the way to the summit of Yr Wyddfa (Snowdon) on a long, steady mountain track. You gradually gain height above stone walls, farms and lakes, often with the historic Snowdon Mountain Railway running parallel to the route. Although it is considered the most straightforward way up, it is still a serious hike with changeable Welsh weather and a full day on your feet. It is ideal if you want a classic UK summit with big views without exposed scrambling.
snowdonia llanberis path wales uk.highlights: Long but gradual path from Llanberis to the summit of Yr Wyddfa (Snowdon). | Wide mountain track for much of the way, making navigation simpler in good visibility. | Far‑reaching views over lakes, ridges and the village of Llanberis far below. | Café and facilities near the summit in season, adding comfort to your hiking day. | Option to combine the walk with a ride on the Snowdon Mountain Railway one way.
snowdonia llanberis path wales uk.bonus: Choose a clear weekday outside peak holidays and start early to enjoy quieter sections of the path and softer morning light over the lakes of Snowdonia.

simien mountains ethiopia.desc: The Simien Mountains in northern Ethiopia rise like a broken fortress of cliffs and high plateaus, with valleys dropping away in dramatic steps for more than a thousand metres. Walking along the escarpment trails you look out over jagged ridges, distant villages and green fields clinging to impossible slopes. This UNESCO‑listed national park is also home to endemic wildlife such as gelada monkeys grazing on the grass, elegant Walia ibex and, with luck, the elusive Ethiopian wolf. You can choose gentle day hikes from comfortable lodges or commit to multi‑day treks that follow the rim from camp to camp.
simien mountains ethiopia.highlights: Spectacular highland scenery with sheer cliffs and sweeping views over the Ethiopian plateau. | Unique wildlife, including large troops of gelada monkeys and rare Walia ibex. | Mix of village life and wild landscapes, with terraced fields right up to the escarpment edge. | Options from short guided walks to challenging multi‑day trekking itineraries. | Cool, crisp mountain climate that contrasts with the lowland heat of much of Ethiopia.
simien mountains ethiopia.bonus: Spend sunset near the escarpment with a guide; watching geladas settle on cliff ledges as the light fades is one of the park’s most memorable scenes.

kalymnos greece.desc: Kalymnos is a Greek island in the Dodecanese where vertical limestone cliffs plunge toward the Aegean and small villages spill down to quiet harbours. It is world‑famous among climbers for its well‑bolted sport routes, yet away from the crags you still find simple tavernas, sponge‑diving history and coves with clear turquoise water. Days easily slide between climbing or hiking on the ridges, swimming at beaches like Massouri and taking a boat across to tiny Telendos for dinner by the sea. It is a relaxed choice if you want an active holiday with a laid‑back island rhythm.
kalymnos greece.highlights: Internationally renowned sport‑climbing destination with hundreds of bolted routes. | Beautiful beaches and rocky coves with clear, warm water for swimming and snorkeling. | Strong maritime heritage, including museums and shops dedicated to sponge diving. | Compact island that is easy to explore by scooter, car or local bus. | Lively but unpretentious atmosphere in villages such as Pothia and Massouri.
kalymnos greece.bonus: Take an evening boat to Telendos, then dine in a waterfront taverna while the sun sets behind the cliffs of Kalymnos across the channel.

red river gorge usa.desc: Hidden in the hills of eastern Kentucky, Red River Gorge is a maze of sandstone cliffs, natural arches and deep forested hollows. You spend your days following winding trails beneath towering walls, picking from hundreds of trad and sport routes or simply wandering to viewpoints over the Daniel Boone National Forest. Evenings slow down around a campfire or a simple cabin, with starry skies and the sound of crickets replacing city noise. It’s a place made for road trips, long weekends with friends and anyone who loves real, rugged outdoor adventure.
red river gorge usa.highlights: Huge sandstone cliffs with thousands of trad and sport routes for all levels. | Network of hiking trails to arches, waterfalls and panoramic forest viewpoints. | Laid-back base camps, cabins and campgrounds close to the crags. | Best seasons in spring and fall with cool, stable climbing conditions.
red river gorge usa.bonus: Take a day to hike out to one of the big natural arches at sunrise for empty trails, soft light and unforgettable photos.

fontainebleau france.desc: Just south of Paris, Fontainebleau’s forest feels like a huge natural playground scattered with smooth sandstone boulders. You wander between pines and heather, spotting painted circuit arrows and choosing problems that suit your level, from kid‑friendly slabs to legendary testpieces. Rest days can mean coffee in the town’s cafés, a stroll around the château or a picnic on warm, sandy clearings. It’s an easy escape if you want world‑class bouldering without being too far from city comfort and culture.
fontainebleau france.highlights: Endless sandstone boulders of every shape and height in a vast forest. | Color‑coded circuits for all levels, from complete beginners to experts. | Soft, sandy landings and short approaches ideal for families and groups. | Quick access from Paris with cafés, bakeries and the château nearby.
fontainebleau france.bonus: Pick a quiet evening session in the Trois Pignons area for golden light, grippy rock and almost no crowds.

railay thailand.desc: Railay, on Thailand’s Krabi coast, is a small peninsula cut off from the world by vertical limestone towers and reached only by boat. Mornings start with longtail rides and turquoise water, then you choose between shaded sport routes, deep‑water soloing, kayaking or simply swimming off white‑sand beaches. As the sun drops, food stalls and beach bars light up while climbers swap stories with backpackers and honeymooners. It’s an easy place to slow down your rhythm, climb as much as you like and still feel you’re on a tropical holiday.
railay thailand.highlights: Dramatic limestone cliffs rising straight from the Andaman Sea. | Boat‑only access that keeps the area compact, walkable and relaxed. | Sport climbing, deep‑water solo, kayaking and island‑hopping from one base. | Sunsets over Railay West and Phra Nang Beach that feel almost unreal.
railay thailand.bonus: Book a late‑afternoon climb above Phra Nang and finish with a swim as the sky turns pink and orange.

frankenjura germany.desc: Frankenjura in northern Bavaria is a patchwork of small limestone crags hidden in rolling hills, fields and dark green forest. You drive short country roads between villages, park by a meadow and walk only a few minutes before pulling on pockets, edges and steep overhangs on routes of every grade. Afternoons blend into beer gardens, half‑timbered houses and bakeries that make rest days almost as tempting as climbing days. It’s a classic road‑trip area for sport climbers who like variety, history and a relaxed rural vibe.
frankenjura germany.highlights: More than a thousand crags and thousands of routes spread across the region. | Typical pocketed limestone with everything from slabs to short powerful roofs. | Very short approaches from village parking to most cliffs. | Traditional Franconian inns and beer gardens perfect after a day on the rock.
frankenjura germany.bonus: Plan at least one easy day to explore a nearby castle or cave and see a different side of Frankenjura beyond the crags.

c se france.desc: Céüse, above the town of Gap in southern France, is a limestone mountain crowned by a huge horseshoe‑shaped cliff. You hike steadily through forest and alpine meadows for nearly an hour, then step out under sweeping walls of pockets and technical faces that have shaped sport climbing history. From easy slabs to long, pumpy testpieces, every line comes with big views over the Hautes‑Alpes and a clear, high‑altitude light. It’s a destination for climbers who enjoy effort and commitment as much as perfect rock and an almost amphitheatre‑like setting.
c se france.highlights: Iconic horseshoe limestone cliff with some of the world’s most famous routes. | Mix of moderate and very hard lines, all on superb pocketed rock. | Cooler high‑altitude climate with best conditions from late spring to autumn. | Panoramic views over valleys and mountains from every sector.
c se france.bonus: Time one evening hike so you top out as the sun sets behind the Alps and the Corniche de Céüse glows orange above the valley.

arco italy.desc: Arco, just north of Lake Garda in northern Italy, feels like a small mountain town built for climbers and outdoor lovers. Sun-warmed limestone walls surround the historic centre, and within minutes you can reach hundreds of crags, via ferratas and panoramic hiking trails looking over the Sarca Valley and the lake. Between one adventure and the next, you wander through cobbled streets for espresso, gelato and gear shops, mixing real Italian life with days spent on the rock. It’s a place where you can push yourself on the wall and still end every evening with relaxed piazza vibes.
arco italy.highlights: Huge choice of sport and multi-pitch routes on quality limestone close to town. | Mild climate that lets you climb comfortably in spring and autumn. | Family-friendly vibe with campgrounds, cafes and easy walks from the centre. | Combine climbing days with swimming or sailing on nearby Lake Garda. | Plenty of guide services and via ferratas if you’re still building confidence.
arco italy.bonus: Hike up to Arco’s hilltop castle at sunset for a wide view of the Sarca Valley glowing in golden light.

el potrero chico mexico.desc: El Potrero Chico, near the town of Hidalgo in northern Mexico, is all about steep limestone towers rising straight out of the desert. From the campground or your simple cabana, you walk a few minutes to stand beneath kilometre-high walls with classic multi-pitch sport routes and friendly single-pitch crags. After a day of exposure and sunshine you refuel on street tacos, cold beer and stories shared with climbers from all over the world. It’s a dream if you want big adventure on a reasonable budget and love the laid-back vibe of a small climbing community.
el potrero chico mexico.highlights: Tall limestone spires with famous multi-pitch sport routes up to many pitches. | Winter sun destination with generally dry, warm conditions. | Campgrounds and cabins right by the canyon, popular with international climbers. | Delicious, affordable Mexican food and basic supplies in nearby Hidalgo. | Local guides and shuttle services that make logistics surprisingly easy.
el potrero chico mexico.bonus: On a rest day, soak in nearby hot springs or take a quick trip to Monterrey for city life and more tacos.

taghia morocco.desc: Taghia, a tiny Berber village hidden deep in Morocco’s Atlas Mountains, feels like the end of the road in the best possible way. Sheer limestone walls wrap around the valley, carving a gorge with long, demanding multi-pitch routes and wild ridgelines for adventurous hikers. Life here is simple: guesthouses, mint tea, mule tracks and evenings under a sky full of stars instead of city lights. It’s a powerful destination if you crave quiet, big walls and a sense of real expedition rather than a polished resort.
taghia morocco.highlights: Remote gorge setting with towering limestone faces up to hundreds of metres high. | World-class multi-pitch routes for experienced, confident climbers. | Guesthouses run by local families offering hearty food and warm hospitality. | Unplugged atmosphere with limited distractions, perfect for focusing on the mountains. | Beautiful hiking possibilities on rest days along mule paths and high plateaus.
taghia morocco.bonus: Take time one evening to sit on a rooftop terrace with mint tea and watch the last light slide off the orange walls of the gorge.

smith rock usa.desc: Smith Rock State Park in central Oregon rises out of the high desert as a maze of orange towers and a river-carved canyon. Thousands of routes wrap around the walls, from beginner-friendly single pitches to steep testpieces that helped define modern sport climbing in the United States. When your forearms need a break, miles of hiking and running trails follow the Crooked River with big views of the spires and distant Cascade volcanoes. It’s an easy choice if you want reliable sun, varied climbing and the relaxed outdoor culture of the Pacific Northwest.
smith rock usa.highlights: Iconic tuff and basalt cliffs with routes for every grade and style. | Generally sunny, dry weather, especially appealing in spring and autumn. | Well-marked trails so non-climbers can hike, trail-run or watch from below. | Campground and small town services nearby for simple, outdoorsy living. | Wildlife sightings from eagles to deer add to the high-desert atmosphere.
smith rock usa.bonus: Set the alarm early at least once to hike Misery Ridge at sunrise and watch the first light hit Monkey Face and the canyon walls.

girona spain.desc: Girona, in Catalonia just inland from the Costa Brava, blends medieval architecture with a modern, sporty vibe. You wander through the stone lanes of the old Jewish Quarter, climb up to the city walls for views over terracotta roofs and then roll back down to colourful houses reflected in the Onyar River. Cafés, tapas bars and creative restaurants keep you fuelled, while bike shops and quiet country roads have turned the city into a training base for cyclists from all over the world. It’s a great pick if you want culture, food and active days in a compact, walkable city.
girona spain.highlights: Beautifully preserved old town with cathedral, city walls and narrow medieval streets. | Colourful riverside houses and bridges that make every stroll feel scenic. | Top destination for road cycling, with varied routes to the coast and mountains. | Lively food scene, from tapas bars to renowned fine-dining restaurants. | Easy access by train or plane and a relaxed, less crowded feel than bigger cities.
girona spain.bonus: For a perfect day, ride a loop through nearby villages in the morning and finish with sunset views from the walls before sharing tapas in the old town.

mallorca spain.desc: Mallorca, the largest of Spain’s Balearic Islands, mixes bright Mediterranean coves with the rugged peaks of the Serra de Tramuntana. As you drive between honey-stone villages, pine-fringed beaches and lively Palma, you move constantly between laid-back seaside life and dramatic mountain roads. Days can flow from coastal walks and boat trips to hidden calas, to tapas in tiny plazas where the evening stays warm long after sunset. Whether you come with kids, friends or your partner, Mallorca lets you shape exactly the island escape you have in mind.
mallorca spain.highlights: Hidden calas with turquoise water for relaxed swimming and snorkeling. | Serra de Tramuntana trails for scenic hikes and bike rides. | Stone villages like Deià and Valldemossa with a slow, authentic rhythm. | Family-friendly island with calm seas, shallow beaches and easy drives.
mallorca spain.bonus: Catch golden hour from a small boat off the west coast: cliffs glow pink while villages light up one by one.

alpe d huez france.desc: High in the French Alps, Alpe d’Huez sits on a sunny plateau above deep valleys and jagged peaks. In winter you spend your days on wide, open pistes between cosy mountain huts, while summer brings hiking paths, bike trails and wildflower meadows. Just below, the legendary road with 21 hairpin bends lets cyclists chase Tour de France dreams on one of the world’s most famous climbs. If you love active holidays in the mountains, from skiing to road cycling and downhill biking, Alpe d’Huez keeps your legs and your camera busy.
alpe d huez france.highlights: Sunny high-altitude resort with long ski runs and varied terrain. | Access to Pic Blanc cable car for spectacular, wide-reaching Alpine views. | Iconic 21-bend climb that road cyclists know from the Tour de France. | Summer bike park and hiking routes starting directly from the village.
alpe d huez france.bonus: Ride the cable car up to Pic Blanc at around 3,300 metres and enjoy a panorama of snow-capped peaks stretching across almost a fifth of France.

stelvio pass italy.desc: Stelvio Pass sweeps across the high Italian Alps in a tight series of bends between Lombardy, South Tyrol and the Swiss border. Driving or riding here means threading your way through 48 hairpins, past sheer rock walls, lingering snowfields and views that change at every turn. At the top, cafés, viewpoints and trailheads invite you to pause, breathe the thin air and decide between a hike, a photo stop or simply another espresso. It’s a dream route for keen cyclists and drivers, but also a spectacular day out for anyone who loves dramatic mountain landscapes.
stelvio pass italy.highlights: One of Italy’s highest paved passes at around 2,758 metres above sea level. | Legendary 48 hairpin bends that test even fit, experienced cyclists. | Panoramic views over glaciers, jagged peaks and deep glacial valleys. | Summer snow sports and high-altitude hiking routes starting near the pass.
stelvio pass italy.bonus: Visit during Stelvio Bike Day, when the road closes to motor traffic and thousands of cyclists climb the pass in complete alpine silence.

boulder usa.desc: Boulder, Colorado sits where the Great Plains rise suddenly into the first folds of the Rocky Mountains. From town you can walk straight into the Flatirons, sandstone slabs laced with trails through pine forest, scree and open meadows, or stay downtown for cafés, street performers and independent shops. Locals fill their days with hiking, trail running, climbing and cycling, then wind down with craft beer or tacos on sunny patios. If you like to mix outdoor adventure with a relaxed, youthful city vibe, Boulder feels like an easy place to settle into for a few days.
boulder usa.highlights: Immediate access to Flatirons hiking trails right from the edge of town. | Miles of paths for running, mountain biking and leisurely creekside walks. | Lively downtown with street music, terrace dining and independent boutiques. | Strong outdoor culture, from climbing and skiing to yoga and wellness events.
boulder usa.bonus: Hike to a Flatirons saddle or the Royal Arch in late afternoon and watch the sun sink behind the Continental Divide as Boulder’s lights flicker on below.

nelson new zealand.desc: Nelson, at the top of New Zealand’s South Island, is a laid-back coastal city wrapped in sunshine, hills and golden sand beaches. From the waterfront and riverside walks you’re only a short drive from Abel Tasman, Kahurangi and Nelson Lakes national parks, where you can kayak, hike or cruise past forested headlands and quiet bays. Back in town you wander between galleries, markets, cafés and small breweries, tasting local seafood and aromatic wines. It’s an easy-going base if you enjoy active days outdoors followed by long, sociable evenings with a glass in hand.
nelson new zealand.highlights: Gateway to Abel Tasman, Kahurangi and Nelson Lakes national parks. | One of New Zealand’s sunniest regions, ideal for year-round outdoor plans. | Mix of beaches, coastal towns, vineyards and scenic cycling routes. | Creative local scene with markets, studios, breweries and relaxed cafés.
nelson new zealand.bonus: Ride a section of Tasman’s Great Taste Trail, stopping at vineyards and viewpoints, then roll back into Nelson as the light turns golden over the bay.

squamish canada.desc: Squamish, British Columbia, sits between towering coastal mountains and the long fjord of Howe Sound, giving you wild scenery almost everywhere you look. Trails wind through mossy forests to panoramic summits, granite cliffs rise straight from the valley floor, and a gondola whisks you to viewpoints without any effort. Between hiking, mountain biking, climbing and paddling, your days fill easily, while evenings feel relaxed in a small town built around outdoor life. Come if you love fresh air, big landscapes and adventure that can be as gentle or as intense as you want.
squamish canada.highlights: Spectacular views over Howe Sound from hikes and the Sea to Sky Gondola. | Huge network of trails, from easy riverside walks to long alpine routes. | World‑class rock climbing and bouldering on the Stawamus Chief and nearby crags. | Excellent mountain biking, kiteboarding and paddling for multi‑sport days in nature. | Easy access from Vancouver along the scenic Sea to Sky Highway.
squamish canada.bonus: Ride the last gondola of the day, then watch sunset paint Howe Sound and the snow‑dusted peaks from the clifftop viewing platforms.

chianti italy.desc: Chianti, in the heart of Tuscany, is a rolling patchwork of vineyards, olive groves and stone farmhouses linked by quiet country roads. Medieval villages crown the hills, wine cellars open their doors for tastings, and long views stretch towards Florence and Siena. Here you take your time: sipping a glass on a terrace, wandering between cypress trees, or cycling gently from village to village. It’s a wonderful choice if you want to slow down, eat incredibly well and feel immersed in a landscape shaped by wine for centuries.
chianti italy.highlights: Classic Tuscan scenery with vineyards, olive groves and lines of cypress trees. | Medieval hilltop towns like Greve, Radda or Castellina to explore at your pace. | Renowned Chianti wines with welcoming estates offering tastings and cellar tours. | Excellent local cuisine, from rustic trattorie to refined countryside restaurants. | Quiet country roads ideal for scenic drives or relaxed cycling between villages.
chianti italy.bonus: Book a sunset tasting on a family‑run estate and watch the hills turn golden while you sample different Chianti wines straight from the source.

yorkshire dales uk.desc: The Yorkshire Dales, in northern England, are a green maze of valleys, dry‑stone walls and limestone hills where sheep outnumber people. Rivers carve waterfalls and deep gorges, footpaths cross meadows and moorland, and stone villages with cosy pubs offer shelter at the end of the day. You can spend your time on gentle walks between villages or tackle longer hikes to high viewpoints without ever losing sight of the rolling countryside. Choose this area if you love wide horizons, honest rural charm and the feeling of stepping into a classic British landscape.
yorkshire dales uk.highlights: Network of well‑marked walking trails through valleys, moorland and over high passes. | Spectacular natural sights such as Malham Cove, Aysgarth Falls and limestone pavements. | Traditional stone villages with welcoming pubs, tearooms and local farm shops. | Great destination for families and walkers thanks to varied, accessible terrain. | Scenic roads and heritage railways offering car‑free ways to explore the park.
yorkshire dales uk.bonus: Take a day to follow a circular walk that links waterfalls, a village pub lunch and a high ridge, finishing as the light softens over the dales.

garden route south africa.desc: South Africa’s Garden Route runs along a lush stretch of coastline where mountain passes drop suddenly towards lagoons, forests and long sandy beaches. You drive between small towns like Knysna and Plettenberg Bay, stopping for short walks on coastal trails, boat trips or tastings at farm stalls. In the nearby national park, indigenous forest hides suspension bridges, river gorges and viewpoints over the Indian Ocean. This road trip is ideal if you like variety: in just a few days you can combine hiking, wildlife watching and slow afternoons by the sea.
garden route south africa.highlights: Ever‑changing scenery with ocean cliffs, lagoons, fynbos and dense indigenous forest. | Charming coastal towns such as Knysna, Wilderness and Plettenberg Bay as stopovers. | Easy access to Garden Route National Park for hiking, canyons and suspension bridges. | Opportunities for whale‑watching in season and encounters with local wildlife. | Flexible self‑drive route with plenty of viewpoints and picnic spots along the way.
garden route south africa.bonus: Plan an early‑morning walk in Tsitsikamma, then cross a suspension bridge as the first light hits the waves rolling into the mouth of the gorge.

north shore oahu usa.desc: The North Shore of Oʻahu is Hawaii’s surf stage, a relaxed stretch of coast where golden beaches meet some of the Pacific’s most powerful winter waves. In summer you find calmer seas for swimming and snorkeling, while food trucks, shrimp shacks and the small town of Haleʻiwa keep the vibe laid‑back. You can spend mornings watching pros tackle reef breaks like Pipeline or Sunset, then head to quieter bays and coastal walks as the light softens. It’s an essential stop if you dream of classic Hawaii scenes with palm trees, surfboards and sunsets over the ocean.
north shore oahu usa.highlights: World‑famous surf breaks with huge winter swells and contests to watch from the sand. | Long sandy beaches such as Waimea Bay and Sunset Beach for swimming in the right season. | Laid‑back Haleʻiwa town with surf shops, cafés and colorful food trucks. | Good snorkeling spots and chances to see turtles in calmer coves. | Easy to combine with the rest of Oʻahu on a day trip or short stay.
north shore oahu usa.bonus: Find a spot on the sand near Sunset Beach, stay until the sky turns deep orange and watch the last surfers ride silhouetted waves.

byron bay australia.desc: Byron Bay, on Australia's easternmost point, blends wild Pacific beaches with a relaxed bohemian town spirit. Long, mellow waves roll into sheltered points like The Pass, while more exposed stretches offer punchier peaks for confident surfers. Off the sand you find yoga studios, organic cafés and markets, plus easy access to rainforest waterfalls and coastal walks up to Cape Byron lighthouse. It's a great choice if you want to learn to surf, chase long rides and unwind in a laid‑back, creative atmosphere.
byron bay australia.highlights: Varied surf spots from gentle beach breaks to iconic right-hand points like The Pass. | Warm water for much of the year and consistent swells along the bay. | Scenic coastal walks to Cape Byron lighthouse with sweeping Pacific views. | Lively boho town vibe with cafés, markets, music and yoga after your surf.
byron bay australia.bonus: Time your visit for sunrise at Cape Byron: watching the first light hit the Pacific while dolphins play below is pure Byron magic.

jeffreys bay south africa.desc: Jeffreys Bay, on South Africa’s Eastern Cape coast, is a laid-back town built around one of the world’s most famous right-hand point breaks. Long, fast walls peel along Supertubes and neighbouring sections, offering rides that seem to go on forever when the winter swells arrive. At the same time, gentler breaks and sandy beaches nearby make it possible for less experienced surfers to get in on the action. Add African sunsets, seafood shacks and easy day trips to reserves where you can spot wildlife, and J‑Bay becomes a surf pilgrimage with a real sense of adventure.
jeffreys bay south africa.highlights: Legendary Supertubes point break with some of the longest, cleanest right-handers on the planet. | Winter swells from May to August bring powerful, reliable surf for confident riders. | Mellower beach breaks and surf schools nearby for intermediates and keen beginners. | Possibility to combine waves with safari day trips and South African food and culture.
jeffreys bay south africa.bonus: On a good day at Supertubes, making a single ride from the top of the point almost to the beach is the kind of wave you’ll remember for life.

ericeira portugal.desc: Ericeira, a white-washed fishing town just north of Lisbon, feels purpose-built for surf-focused escapes. A string of bays and reef breaks within a short drive form Europe’s first World Surfing Reserve, serving everything from mellow summer rollers to hollow winter lines at spots like Ribeira d’Ilhas and Coxos. Back in town, cobbled streets, seafood taverns and Atlantic sunsets from the clifftop promenade slow the pace right down. It’s a great choice if you want reliable waves, Portuguese charm and the flexibility to mix surf sessions with relaxed evenings in a real village atmosphere.
ericeira portugal.highlights: Compact stretch of coastline with many different breaks for all levels close together. | World Surfing Reserve status and very consistent Atlantic swell throughout the year. | Characterful old town with cobbled lanes, cafés and excellent fresh seafood. | Easy access from Lisbon yet a slower, small-town feel once you arrive.
ericeira portugal.bonus: Don’t miss a golden-hour session at Ribeira d’Ilhas, then walk up to the miradouro above the bay for one of the best sunset views on the coast.

hossegor france.desc: Hossegor, on France’s Landes coast, has long been considered the European capital of beach-break barrels. A straight line of sand backed by dunes and pine forest focuses Atlantic swells into fast, powerful peaks at spots like La Gravière, while neighbouring stretches offer more forgiving banks on smaller days. In town you’ll find stylish cafés, surf shops and a laid-back holiday buzz, plus lakes and bike paths threading the forest just behind the shore. Choose Hossegor if you crave punchy waves, a strong surf culture and the option to mix heavy sessions with easygoing French seaside living.
hossegor france.highlights: World-class sand-bottom barrels at Hossegor’s main peaks when autumn swells arrive. | Plenty of nearby banks and towns like Seignosse and Capbreton for different conditions. | Long dune-backed beaches, pine forests and lakes ideal for walks, runs or bike rides. | Lively but relaxed French surf town vibe with cafés, markets, events and good food.
hossegor france.bonus: Time a trip for early autumn and you might watch pros compete at heavy low-tide peaks in the morning, then score your own glassy session as the wind drops in the evening.

tamarindo costa rica.desc: Tamarindo, on Costa Rica’s north-Pacific coast, is a long, palm-fringed bay where surf rhythm sets the schedule. Sand-bottom peaks along the main beach serve up forgiving waves for beginners and intermediates, while nearby spots like Playa Grande and Playa Langosta offer punchier options as your confidence grows. The water is warm all year and the biggest swells usually arrive in the lush green season from April to October. Off the board you’ve got sunset bars, wildlife boat tours in the estuary and easy access to national parks. It’s an easygoing base if you want tropical waves without overcomplicating your trip.
tamarindo costa rica.highlights: User-friendly beach breaks in town ideal for first take-offs and smooth progression. | Year-round surf with more powerful, consistent swells in the April–October green season. | Quick access by boat or car to breaks like Playa Grande, Langosta and Avellanas. | Relaxed Central American surf-town vibe with sunsets, seafood and plenty of schools and camps.
tamarindo costa rica.bonus: Join an evening boat tour through the mangrove estuary after your session: spotting crocodiles, birds and maybe turtles while the sky turns orange is a classic Tamarindo bonus.

raglan new zealand.desc: Raglan, on New Zealand’s wild west coast, is a laid-back surf town wrapped around a tranquil harbour and long black-sand beaches. Out at Manu Bay and Whale Bay you can watch near-perfect left-hand point breaks peeling along the rocks, while Ngarunui Beach offers softer waves and wide sands for learning to surf or simply playing in the Tasman Sea. Between sessions you wander between cafés, food trucks and creative little galleries that keep the village buzzing without ever feeling crowded. Come if you love salty hair, big skies and the easy rhythm of surf-town life.
raglan new zealand.highlights: World-famous left-hand point breaks at Manu Bay and Whale Bay. | Beginner-friendly waves and surf schools at Ngarunui Beach. | Black-sand coastline with sweeping Tasman Sea sunsets. | Compact harbour village with cafés, bars and creative boutiques. | Laid-back Kiwi vibe, ideal for slow, surf-focused days.
raglan new zealand.bonus: Drive or hike up to the clifftop lookouts above Ngarunui Beach for a sunset panorama of sky, rolling lines of swell and Raglan below.

nazar portugal.desc: Nazaré, on Portugal’s Atlantic coast, looks at first like a classic fishing town with whitewashed houses, a sweeping sandy bay and tiled squares full of cafés. Just around the headland at Praia do Norte, the underwater canyon suddenly wakes up the ocean, creating some of the biggest rideable waves on the planet from late autumn to early spring. On calmer days you stroll the seafront promenade, take the funicular up to the Sítio clifftop district and watch the lighthouse standing guard over the break. Come if you want to feel the raw power of the Atlantic without giving up good food and a relaxed Portuguese vibe.
nazar portugal.highlights: Home of Praia do Norte, world-famous for record-breaking big-wave surfing. | Dramatic viewpoints from Sítio and the São Miguel Arcanjo lighthouse. | Traditional fishing town feel with seafood restaurants and local bars. | Different moods by season: heavy winter swells, mellow summer beach days. | Easy coastal stop within a wider road trip through central Portugal.
nazar portugal.bonus: Visit on a big-swell day, stand by the lighthouse rails and feel the cliffs tremble as walls of water detonate below.

tofino canada.desc: Tofino, at the remote western edge of Vancouver Island in British Columbia, feels like a little surf outpost surrounded by ocean, forest and fog. Long Beach, Cox Bay and Chesterman Beach stretch for kilometres, offering smooth beach breaks, chilled beach walks and year-round surf sessions in a wetsuit. Just behind the sand begins Pacific Rim National Park Reserve, where cedar giants, mossy boardwalks and viewpoints over Clayoquot Sound immerse you in temperate rainforest. If you like wild nature, cool-water waves, craft beer and cosy evenings watching Pacific storms through a big window, Tofino will feel instantly right.
tofino canada.highlights: Kilometres of sandy surf beaches within Pacific Rim National Park Reserve. | Year-round beach breaks with plenty of surf schools and rentals. | Dense temperate rainforest trails with giant cedar and spruce trees. | Whale-watching, bear-watching and kayak tours in Clayoquot Sound. | Chilled Canadian surf town vibe with cafés, bakeries and breweries.
tofino canada.bonus: Plan a winter storm-watching weekend and listen to the Pacific roar outside while you stay warm by the fire in a lodge facing the ocean.

mentawai islands indonesia.desc: The Mentawai Islands, scattered off the west coast of Sumatra in Indonesia, form a string of jungle-covered isles floating in luminous turquoise water. Fast boats and surf charters link small camps and homestays with reef passes around Siberut, Sipora and the Pagai islands, where Indian Ocean swells wrap into perfect peaks, playful shoulders or hollow barrels depending on the day. When you need a break from the lineup, palm-fringed beaches, snorkelling above coral gardens and simple villages keep the pace slow and human. Pick Mentawai if you dream of warm-water surfing far from crowds and don’t mind trading city comforts for raw, tropical energy.
mentawai islands indonesia.highlights: Remote archipelago off Sumatra with dozens of world-class reef breaks. | Warm, glassy Indian Ocean waves ideal for intermediate and advanced surfers. | Choice of surf charters, boat trips and intimate island camps. | Palm-lined beaches, snorkelling reefs and lush jungle just behind the sand. | Strong sense of adventure and local Mentawai culture away from mass tourism.
mentawai islands indonesia.bonus: Join a surf boat that anchors overnight by different reefs so you wake up, drink coffee on deck and paddle straight into uncrowded morning glass.

great blue hole belize.desc: The Great Blue Hole sits in the middle of Lighthouse Reef Atoll off the coast of Belize, a perfect dark-blue circle cut into a lagoon of pale turquoise water. This immense marine sinkhole drops more than a hundred metres straight down, with vertical walls and ancient stalactites that experienced divers can explore on guided deep dives. Most day trips combine the Blue Hole with nearby reef sites and sandy cays, so you can snorkel among corals and tropical fish even if you stay at shallower depths. Prefer to keep dry? Short scenic flights trace a loop over the atoll, revealing the full ring of reef and the Belize Barrier Reef stretching to the horizon.
great blue hole belize.highlights: Iconic circular sinkhole inside Lighthouse Reef Atoll, off the coast of Belize. | Advanced deep dive with sheer limestone walls and hanging stalactites. | Day tours that combine the Blue Hole with nearby reef and cay snorkelling. | Scenic helicopter or small-plane flights for unforgettable aerial photos. | Part of the UNESCO-listed Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System.
great blue hole belize.bonus: Book a dawn flight from the cayes and watch the sun rise over the Caribbean while the Great Blue Hole glows like a deep sapphire below you.

komodo national park indonesia.desc: Komodo National Park stretches across rugged Indonesian islands where burnt-orange hills drop into clear, current-swept seas. From Labuan Bajo you board a boat and spend your days drifting over coral gardens, manta cleaning stations and steep reefs alive with reef fish. Back on land you hike sunbaked trails to lookout points and meet the famous Komodo dragons with a park ranger. It is an adventurous escape if you love wild nature, small groups and the feeling of being far from everything.
komodo national park indonesia.highlights: Close encounters with Komodo dragons on guided walks through savanna hills | Drift and reef dives with manta rays, sharks and dense schools of reef fish | Island-hopping by boat between Komodo, Padar, Rinca and tiny deserted bays | Sunrise or sunset hikes to viewpoints with sweeping views over turquoise bays | Mix of liveaboard trips and day boats to suit different budgets and experience
komodo national park indonesia.bonus: Sleep on deck under an immense sky of stars while your boat quietly anchors in a sheltered Komodo bay.

great barrier reef cairns australia.desc: From tropical Cairns you reach the Great Barrier Reef in a short boat ride, swapping city streets for a floating world of coral. Day boats and liveaboards take you to outer reef sites where you snorkel above bommies, drift past drop-offs and, if you wish, try an introductory or certified dive. On deck you relax in the sun while marine guides explain the fragile ecosystem beneath you. It is an easy, colourful way to experience one of the planet’s most famous natural wonders.
great barrier reef cairns australia.highlights: Convenient base in Cairns with many departures to different outer reef sites | Snorkelling over shallow coral gardens ideal for first-time reef visitors and families | Options for introductory dives, certified dives and longer liveaboard adventures | Onboard briefings from guides who share stories about reef life and conservation | Warm tropical climate and cruising catamarans that make the day relaxed and comfortable
great barrier reef cairns australia.bonus: Book an overnight trip to sleep at sea and watch the reef glow with bioluminescence before a sunrise snorkel when the water is at its calmest.

sipadan malaysia.desc: Sipadan is a tiny emerald island rising abruptly from the deep Celebes Sea, surrounded by drop-offs that fall hundreds of metres. You stay on nearby Mabul or Kapalai and ride out by boat each morning to drift along coral walls packed with turtles, reef sharks and swirling schools of fish. Strict permits and limited daily numbers keep the atmosphere calm and focused on the diving. It is a dream destination for experienced divers who want big marine life, clear water and the feeling of being on a true ocean outpost.
sipadan malaysia.highlights: Legendary wall dives where turtles glide past within arm’s reach on almost every dive | Schooling barracuda, jacks and bumphead parrotfish that often fill your entire field of vision | Permit system that limits daily visitors and helps keep the reefs healthy and uncrowded | Easy access to additional sites around Mabul and Kapalai for macro and relaxed afternoon dives | Warm tropical water with generally good visibility that flatters underwater photography
sipadan malaysia.bonus: Time one of your dives for sunrise and watch the reef wake up as barracuda tornadoes, hunting jacks and first light transform the wall into a living theatre.

red sea marsa alam egypt.desc: Marsa Alam is a laid-back town on Egypt’s southern Red Sea coast, where desert mountains meet calm, turquoise bays. Resorts stretch along the shoreline with house reefs just a short swim from the jetty, ideal for unhurried snorkelling or easy boat dives. Out at sea you can explore coral gardens, drop-offs and seagrass meadows that sometimes attract turtles and gentle dugongs. Compared with busier northern resorts, Marsa Alam feels quieter and more natural, a good match if you prefer long days in the water and peaceful evenings under a bright sky of stars.
red sea marsa alam egypt.highlights: Long fringing reefs accessible directly from hotel jetties for relaxed snorkelling | Boat trips to outer reefs with colourful coral, turtles and plenty of reef fish | Chances, though never guaranteed, to spot dolphins or dugongs in protected bays | Good selection of all-inclusive resorts yet with a generally calm and spacious feel | Year-round sunshine and warm water that invite repeated dips throughout the day
red sea marsa alam egypt.bonus: Set aside one evening for a desert excursion: leave the coast after sunset, drink sweet tea under the Milky Way and then return to sleep by the sea.

bonaire caraibi olandesi.desc: Bonaire, in the Dutch Caribbean, is a low-key island where everyday life revolves around the sea and the trade winds. Almost the entire coastline is a protected marine park, so you simply load your pickup with tanks and step into the water from shore to explore coral slopes, soft sponges and curious tarpon. Between dives you might drive through cactus-dotted hills or relax at Lac Bay, where steady winds power windsurfers across a shallow lagoon. The island suits independent travellers who value freedom, easy logistics and long, unhurried days in the sun.
bonaire caraibi olandesi.highlights: World-renowned shore diving with clearly marked sites accessible directly from the road | Well-protected reefs with abundant fish, healthy corals and minimal boat traffic | Lac Bay’s shallow lagoon offering ideal conditions for windsurfing at many levels | Compact island with short driving distances between dive spots, beaches and town | Strong focus on marine conservation and a relaxed, safe atmosphere on land
bonaire caraibi olandesi.bonus: Plan at least one night dive on a house reef to watch hunting tarpon use your torchlight while tiny bioluminescent flashes sparkle in the dark water.

palau palau.desc: Palau is a remote Pacific island nation where emerald jungle clings to limestone Rock Islands rising out of electric-blue lagoons. From the small town of Koror, boats whisk you through this maze to reefs like Blue Corner and German Channel, famous for manta rays, sharks and turtles. You drift above coral gardens that still feel remarkably healthy, with visibility so clear it seems you’re hovering in mid-air. It’s ideal if you dream of long days on the water, serious snorkeling or diving, and seascapes that feel truly far from mass tourism.
palau palau.highlights: Boat excursions through UNESCO-listed Rock Islands and hidden turquoise lagoons | World-class snorkeling and diving with manta rays, reef sharks and turtles | Remarkably healthy coral reefs and dramatic drop-offs like Blue Corner | Professional local operators based in Koror for easy day trips by boat | Remote Micronesian atmosphere with very little shore development
palau palau.bonus: If conditions allow, ask about visiting Jellyfish Lake, a surreal marine lake where you can float among thousands of non-stinging golden jellyfish.

bonaire caribbean netherlands.desc: Malapascua Island, off the northern tip of Cebu in the Philippines, mixes laid-back village life with some of the world’s most unusual diving. Before sunrise, boats head out to Monad Shoal, one of the few places where you can regularly see pelagic thresher sharks gliding up from the deep. Later in the day you snorkel or dive colourful reefs, relax on the powdery sand of Bounty Beach and wander tiny lanes lined with palm trees. It’s ideal if you want big-animal encounters but still enjoy a small, friendly island where you can walk everywhere barefoot.
bonaire caribbean netherlands.highlights: Dawn dives at Monad Shoal with graceful pelagic thresher sharks | White-sand Bounty Beach with simple bars and sunset views | Plenty of dive sites with reefs, walls, wrecks and night dives | Compact island you can explore on foot, with a relaxed village feel | Good mix of budget guesthouses and comfortable dive resorts
bonaire caribbean netherlands.bonus: Join a local boat at sunrise to watch thresher sharks being cleaned by tiny reef fish — an otherworldly scene you’ll replay in your mind for years.

similan islands thailand.desc: The Similan Islands, off Thailand’s Andaman coast, are a small archipelago of white-sand beaches, granite boulders and some of the country’s clearest water. Boats leave mainly from Khao Lak to reach this marine national park, where you can drift over hard-coral gardens, swim above huge rock formations and, in season, join liveaboards that hop between different islands. Visibility is usually excellent and currents range from gentle to exciting, making it easy to mix relaxed snorkeling with more challenging dives. It’s a great choice if you want a classic “tropical island plus dive boat” holiday rather than a big resort scene.
similan islands thailand.highlights: Day trips and liveaboards from Khao Lak into Similan Marine National Park | Powder-soft beaches backed by jungle and rounded granite boulders | Crystal-clear water with reefs, pinnacles and dramatic underwater rockscapes | Good chance to see turtles, schooling fish and, in season, manta rays | Park closes part of the year to let reefs recover, keeping nature in good shape
similan islands thailand.bonus: Climb the viewpoint on Koh Similan’s Sail Rock between dives for a wide-angle view of the lagoon, jungle and scattered islets.

komodo labuan bajo indonesia.desc: Labuan Bajo, on the western tip of Flores in Indonesia, is a colourful harbour town and the main gateway to Komodo National Park. From here you spend your days island-hopping to rugged hills, pink-tinted beaches and bays where manta rays cruise through clear, current-swept water. On Komodo or Rinca you hike with rangers to spot the famous Komodo dragons in their natural habitat, then return to town for sunset over a sea filled with boats. It’s a brilliant base if you want a mix of wildlife encounters, viewpoints, snorkelling and a lively, up-and-coming seaside vibe.
komodo labuan bajo indonesia.highlights: Easy boat access from Labuan Bajo to multiple islands in Komodo National Park | Guided walks to see wild Komodo dragons on Komodo and Rinca | Spectacular viewpoints on Padar Island with bays in different shades of blue | Snorkelling and diving sites with manta rays, turtles and rich coral reefs | Harbourfront cafés and rooftop bars perfect for dramatic sunset views
komodo labuan bajo indonesia.bonus: Book a small-group early-morning cruise that combines Padar’s sunrise hike, dragon-spotting and a stop at a pink beach, so you experience the park before most crowds arrive.

aitutaki cook islands.desc: Aitutaki, in the Cook Islands, feels like the classic South Pacific lagoon you see on postcards, only real. A ring of small motu encircles a vast, shallow lagoon in shades of turquoise and milky blue, perfect for lazy cruises, kayaking and long swims over sandbars. Day tours take you to tiny islets like One Foot Island, where palm trees lean over water so clear you can count every fish and giant clam below. It’s a magical choice if you want slow days on the water, barefoot luxury and a romantic, far-away-from-everything atmosphere.
aitutaki cook islands.highlights: Iconic turquoise lagoon surrounded by palm-fringed motu islets | Lagoon cruises with snorkelling stops, sandbars and beach barbecues | Chance to visit One Foot Island and its tiny passport-stamping post office | Excellent snorkelling with colourful reef fish, turtles and giant clams | Intimate resorts and bungalows that balance comfort with laid-back island life
aitutaki cook islands.bonus: For an unforgettable extra, join a small-boat tour that anchors on a sandbar in the middle of the lagoon, so you can step straight into warm, waist-deep water on all sides.

hol chan ambergris caye belize.desc: Hol Chan Marine Reserve off Ambergris Caye in Belize lets you slip straight into the heart of the Belize Barrier Reef. In shallow, protected waters you drift above bright coral heads, schools of tropical fish and grazing sea turtles before the bottom suddenly drops into the famous cut in the reef. Local guides know where nurse sharks and rays often cruise past, keeping the experience relaxed even if it’s your first time snorkeling. It’s an easy half‑day escape if you want Caribbean sea life without long boat rides.
hol chan ambergris caye belize.highlights: Easy boat ride from San Pedro with short travel time to the reef. | Shallow coral gardens perfect for beginners and confident swimmers together. | Frequent encounters with sea turtles, nurse sharks, rays and colorful reef fish. | Protected marine reserve with clear Caribbean water and good visibility most days. | Option to combine Hol Chan with Shark Ray Alley on the same tour.
hol chan ambergris caye belize.bonus: Ask about late‑afternoon trips: gliding over the reef as the sun sets behind Ambergris Caye makes the colors and silhouettes underwater feel even more dramatic.

kealakekua bay big island usa.desc: Kealakekua Bay on Hawaii’s Big Island is a sheltered, cliff‑ringed inlet where coral gardens and island history share the same clear water. You slide in from the boat straight into a designated marine life conservation district, with lava rock formations, branching coral and clouds of reef fish visible just a few metres below the surface. Many trips pause at the white Captain Cook monument on the shore, adding context to the landscape you’re floating in. Choose this bay if you enjoy snorkeling that mixes scenery, stories and relaxed tropical vibes.
kealakekua bay big island usa.highlights: Usually calm morning conditions with very good underwater visibility. | Snorkeling inside a protected marine life conservation district on the Kona coast. | Steep lava cliffs and lush slopes create a dramatic natural amphitheatre. | Ideal for confident swimmers who like spending longer time in the water. | Chance to spot dolphins or other wildlife from the boat on the way.
kealakekua bay big island usa.bonus: Ask about small‑group or kayak trips that reach the monument early, before most tour boats arrive, for a quieter swim over the reef.

apo island philippines.desc: Apo Island in the central Philippines is a tiny volcanic island surrounded by clear water and a community‑run marine reserve famous for sea turtles. Just offshore, shallow reefs and seagrass beds shelter green turtles that graze calmly while snorkellers drift above them, along with dense patches of hard coral and clouds of small fish. On the beach simple boats, palm trees and a relaxed village atmosphere remind you how remote you really are. It’s a great pick if you want easy turtle encounters, healthy coral and a laid‑back island feel in one stop.
apo island philippines.highlights: Short outrigger boat ride from the Negros coast to a small, low‑key island. | High chance to snorkel respectfully alongside green sea turtles in shallow water. | Well‑known marine sanctuary with colourful hard corals and plenty of reef fish. | Small village atmosphere with basic facilities and a very local vibe. | Good conditions in the dry season, with trips usually possible year‑round.
apo island philippines.bonus: Book a local guide for the turtle sanctuary area: they not only protect the animals, they’ll also point out subtle reef details you might miss.

isola di mafia tanzania.desc: Mafia Island off the coast of Tanzania feels a world away from the busier resorts of the Indian Ocean. Inside the Mafia Island Marine Park you snorkel above coral gardens, sandbanks and seagrass beds where reef fish and turtles are common, and from October to March the western side of the island is famous for surface‑feeding whale sharks that can sometimes be seen from the boat. Small lodges, quiet beaches and starry nights keep the atmosphere low‑key and unhurried. It’s an inspiring choice if you want big marine encounters without losing the sense of a sleepy island.
isola di mafia tanzania.highlights: Quieter alternative to larger Tanzanian islands with a strong “off‑the‑beaten‑path” feel. | Snorkeling and diving inside a protected marine park with reefs, sandbars and lagoons. | Seasonal chance to swim with gentle whale sharks, usually October to March. | Good mix of turtle, reef‑fish and macro life for underwater photographers. | Simple villages and small lodges create an authentic, relaxed coastal atmosphere.
isola di mafia tanzania.bonus: Plan at least one full day dedicated to whale sharks: heading out early with an experienced spotter crew greatly increases your chances of an unhurried, respectful encounter.

hol chan marine reserve belize.desc: Ningaloo Reef on Western Australia’s remote Coral Coast is one of the few places in the world where you can swim with whale sharks along a fringing reef that lies just offshore. From Exmouth or Coral Bay you cross shallow turquoise water to reach channels where whale sharks, manta rays and, in season, humpback whales cruise past, while the inner reef still gives shelter to turtles and reef fish even after recent coral‑bleaching events. On land the red desert meets empty white beaches, so every day feels like part of a road trip along the edge of the outback. Choose Ningaloo if you’re drawn to big‑animal encounters in a raw, wide‑open landscape.
hol chan marine reserve belize.highlights: One of the world’s best spots to swim with whale sharks, mainly from March to August. | Snorkeling from the beach at spots where the reef lies just a short swim offshore. | Chance to see manta rays, turtles and, later in the year, migrating humpback whales. | Remote coastal towns with clear night skies and a relaxed, outdoorsy atmosphere. | Licensed eco‑tours with strict rules to keep wildlife interactions safe and respectful.
hol chan marine reserve belize.bonus: Try to book on a tour that includes both an outer‑reef whale shark swim and a gentle drift snorkel over the inner lagoon, so you experience Ningaloo’s big and small wonders in one day.

isla mujeres mexico.desc: Isla Mujeres sits just off the coast of Cancún, but life here runs on island time. You’ll split your days between the powdery sand of Playa Norte, calm turquoise water and colourful reefs where rays and tropical fish drift around you. Rent a golf cart to circle the island, stop at Punta Sur for wind‑swept cliff views and end the evening with your feet in the sand at a beach bar. It’s an easy escape if you want relaxed Caribbean vibes with light adventures on and under the water.
isla mujeres mexico.highlights: Shallow, turquoise water and soft sand on iconic Playa Norte. | Snorkeling trips to nearby reefs and the underwater sculpture park MUSA. | Compact island you explore by golf cart, bike or on foot. | Plenty of casual beach bars and taquerías for sunset dinners. | Seasonal boat tours to swim near gentle whale sharks in open water.
isla mujeres mexico.bonus: Join a small‑group sunset cruise around Isla Mujeres: watch the sky turn pink over the Caribbean while you sip something cold and glide past the shoreline.

koh tao thailand.desc: Perched in the Gulf of Thailand, Koh Tao is a compact island where jungle‑covered hills tumble down to small coves of bright, blue water. By day you can learn to dive or simply snorkel above coral gardens at spots like Japanese Gardens or Shark Bay, watching turtles and schools of fish glide past. In the late afternoon you ride a scooter up to a viewpoint, then drift back to Sairee Beach for sunset cocktails with your feet in the sand. It’s a great match if you love an easygoing island vibe mixed with underwater adventure.
koh tao thailand.highlights: World‑class beginner‑friendly diving schools with affordable certification courses. | Snorkeling bays with clear water, coral gardens and frequent turtle encounters. | Steep viewpoints offering panoramas over jungle hills and scattered bays. | Relaxed nightlife on Sairee Beach with beach bars and fire shows. | Compact size makes it simple to explore by scooter or long‑tail boat.
koh tao thailand.bonus: Set aside one evening for a hike to a west‑facing viewpoint above Sairee Beach: watch the sun sink behind tiny islets while long‑tail boats drift below.

fernando de noronha brazil.desc: Far off Brazil’s northeast coast, Fernando de Noronha is a protected archipelago where emerald hills fall into bays of incredibly clear water. You spend your days hiking between viewpoints and secluded coves like Baía do Sancho and Baía dos Porcos, often voted among the world’s most beautiful beaches, then slipping into the sea to snorkel with turtles, reef sharks and colourful fish. Strict visitor numbers keep the islands quiet and the marine park remarkably intact. It’s a dream destination if you’re happy to travel a little farther for wild scenery and unforgettable time in the ocean.
fernando de noronha brazil.highlights: Remote island setting with limited daily visitors and a preserved atmosphere. | Spectacular beaches such as Baía do Sancho, framed by cliffs and jungle. | Exceptional snorkeling and diving with turtles, rays and reef sharks. | Viewpoints and coastal trails offering sweeping Atlantic panoramas. | Strong focus on conservation, giving every swim a true wilderness feel.
fernando de noronha brazil.bonus: Stay out for sunset at Forte do Boldró: from the old stone walls you watch the sun drop behind Morro Dois Irmãos, painting the whole bay gold.

mnemba atoll tanzania.desc: Off the north‑east coast of Zanzibar, Mnemba Atoll is a small reef system wrapped around a private island and some of the clearest water in Tanzania. Boats drop you on the edge of the marine reserve, where you drift over colourful coral gardens, schools of tropical fish and, with luck, curious turtles or dolphins. Between snorkel sessions you relax on a sandbank that appears with the low tide, surrounded by nothing but sea and sky. It’s made for travellers who dream of a castaway feeling but still appreciate the comfort and guidance of an organised boat trip.
mnemba atoll tanzania.highlights: Famous marine reserve with high visibility and thriving coral formations. | Regular encounters with reef fish, turtles and sometimes playful dolphins. | Easy day trips by boat from Zanzibar’s main island, including gear and guide. | Short swims from the boat – suitable even for less experienced snorkelers. | Sandbank stops that deliver that postcard‑perfect, deserted‑island moment.
mnemba atoll tanzania.bonus: Ask your crew to start early: being one of the first boats at Mnemba means you’ll float above the reef almost alone while the morning light floods the water.

st andrews scotland uk.desc: On Scotland’s east coast, St Andrews combines windswept North Sea beaches with stone lanes, medieval ruins and the legendary fairways of the Old Course. Mornings might be spent walking along West Sands, where waves roll in beside the town and the film Chariots of Fire was shot, or teeing off on one of several historic golf courses. In the afternoon you wander between the university quadrangles, castle and cathedral remains, ducking into cafés and pubs when the sea breeze picks up. It’s a character‑rich base for travellers who like their coastal escapes with a heavy dose of history and golf.
st andrews scotland uk.highlights: Iconic Old Course and several other public links for every level of golfer. | Two‑mile‑long West Sands beach with wide skies and North Sea views. | Atmospheric ruins of the castle and cathedral overlooking the shoreline. | Lively university town feel with cosy pubs, cafés and independent shops. | Easy access to other Fife fishing villages along the scenic coastal route.
st andrews scotland uk.bonus: Climb St Rule’s Tower in the former cathedral grounds on a clear day: the 360‑degree view takes in red‑roofed streets, dunes and endless sea.

pebble beach usa.desc: Pebble Beach on California’s Monterey Peninsula lets you play golf where the Pacific Ocean crashes at the edge of the fairways. Iconic holes hug rugged cliffs while 17‑Mile Drive and white-sand coves frame every swing. Between rounds you can walk coastal trails, watch sea otters and seals in the surf, or explore nearby Carmel and Monterey’s lively waterfront. The vibe is relaxed yet unmistakably upscale, ideal if you dream of combining once-in-a-lifetime golf with ocean views, fine dining and unhurried spa time.
pebble beach usa.highlights: Oceanfront championship courses with world-famous cliffside holes. | Mild coastal climate so you can play most of the year. | Scenic 17‑Mile Drive and Pacific beaches within minutes. | Upscale resorts, spas and restaurants tailored to golfers. | Easy access to Carmel, Monterey Bay and local wine country.
pebble beach usa.bonus: Book a late-afternoon tee time: walking up the 18th as the sun drops into the Pacific feels like the ending of your own golf movie.

scottsdale tpc usa.desc: At TPC Scottsdale in Arizona you tee off surrounded by the wide-open Sonoran Desert, with cactus-lined fairways and distant mountain ridges. The Stadium Course, famous for hosting the WM Phoenix Open, mixes risk-and-reward holes with an energetic tournament feel even on ordinary days. Off the course you can relax by the pool, explore Scottsdale’s restaurants and bars or head out for hikes among red rocks and saguaro cacti. It’s a great choice if you love sunshine golf, lively evenings and a touch of PGA TOUR atmosphere.
scottsdale tpc usa.highlights: Championship courses set in the landscapes of the Sonoran Desert. | Dry, sunny climate ideal for winter and shoulder-season golf. | Signature Stadium Course holes that recreate a tour-style experience. | Easy access to Scottsdale’s dining, nightlife and shopping districts. | Nearby hiking trails and desert tours for non-golf days.
scottsdale tpc usa.bonus: Try to play the Stadium Course on a busy day: the amphitheatre-style 16th hole becomes even more fun with a cheering crowd around the green.

ras al khaimah uae.desc: Ras Al Khaimah in the United Arab Emirates brings together long sandy beaches, rugged Hajar Mountains and rolling desert in a single trip. You can sunbathe on family-friendly resorts along Al Marjan Island, then drive inland to Jebel Jais for cool air, viewpoints and record-breaking ziplines. Between sea and mountains there are wadis to hike, historic forts to explore and evening desert camps under starry skies. It’s a great alternative if you like the idea of the UAE’s sunshine and comfort with a calmer, more natural atmosphere than Dubai.
ras al khaimah uae.highlights: Wide choice of beach resorts along the Arabian Gulf. | Jebel Jais mountain road with panoramic viewpoints and zipline park. | Desert experiences from camel rides to dune bashing and stargazing. | Milder temperatures than inland cities during the hottest months. | Good value compared with more famous Emirati destinations.
ras al khaimah uae.bonus: Plan a day that starts with sunrise on the beach and ends with sunset in the Hajar Mountains for a striking contrast in just a few hours.

cascais portugal.desc: Cascais on Portugal’s Atlantic coast feels like a relaxed seaside town and a refined resort at the same time. You wander between tiled streets, Belle Époque villas and a small marina before reaching sandy bays or the long oceanfront promenade towards Estoril. Nearby, Guincho Beach brings wild Atlantic waves and the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park adds forests and cliffs. With easy train access from Lisbon, Cascais works just as well for a romantic escape as for a few slow days by the sea with friends or family.
cascais portugal.highlights: Charming historic centre with tiled houses, cafés and small museums. | Several town beaches plus wilder Guincho Beach close by. | Scenic coastal promenade and cycling path towards Estoril. | Easy 30–40 minute train connection from central Lisbon. | Access to Sintra-Cascais Natural Park for hikes and viewpoints.
cascais portugal.bonus: Take an evening stroll along the waterfront to the Santa Marta lighthouse and watch the lights of the bay switch on one by one.

la manga spain.desc: La Manga on Spain’s Murcia coast stretches between the Mediterranean Sea and the shallow Mar Menor lagoon, giving you two very different waters in one stay. At La Manga Club you find three renowned golf courses, tennis and padel courts, a spa and plenty of space for active holidays. Beyond the fairways you can explore sandy beaches, small coves and coastal viewpoints looking across both seas.
